name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 26 November 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, there is a little emotion today, returning to Strasbourg, after many months of a pandemic that has stopped our countries, which has stopped the European Union, which has stopped the world and I am here with you today at the headquarters of our institution to open our December session and also to convey to the city of Strasbourg and to the French authorities a message of friendship , of solidarity, of cooperation, with our Members, all the political groups, a warm greeting to the citizens of the city of Strasbourg. It is also an emotion for us to remember the attack two years ago, on 11 December 2018, that struck the city of Strasbourg and our institution. My thoughts with you go out to the victims, their families and their friends. Strasbourg and its region have suffered deeply from Covid-19, a virus that has killed so many of our fellow citizens. We will end this year with almost five hundred thousand dead. We are aware of the human, social and economic difficulties that the city is facing. Parliament wants to be at your side and we have been happy to be able to provide with some solidarity initiatives, to try to meet the difficulties of citizens of this city, to provide a solidarity canteen and screening center for Covid-19, because we have always thought that it is the task of the institutions to set a good example. It is our common wish to hold our plenary sessions again in this Chamber. Parliament has acted with determination and has quickly implemented the necessary steps to continue its work in the difficult circumstances that have imposed on us in recent months, but we can also be proud that Covid has not stopped the institutions and has not stopped the European Parliament and therefore has not stopped the development of European democracy and its institutions. Parliament can be proud to have exercised its prerogatives and to have kept European democracy open. After my opening, the session will, as you know, resume from Brussels in full compliance with the measures in force for the protection of public health. But we will soon return to Strasbourg, this is our home, as it is written in the Treaties, but that is what is written in the history of the European Union. The Covid-19 pandemic, as you know, is having very profound social and economic consequences for our citizens and businesses. We will emerge stronger and more united from this crisis, I am convinced. Just as I am convinced that the challenges we face in the future will be able to count on a Union that will be more resilient and more capable of meeting the challenges of the future, and the measures we have taken in recent months will enable future generations to respond better, to face more strongly the challenges that the global world will present to us. It is time for a truly European vision, and I believe that our public opinion and our citizens are also realising that a more efficient, stronger Europe is a guarantee of their response, that no one alone could do it. Let us remember at the moment a forward-thinking man, a man who gave a great deal to the European Union and its institutions, former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing. He left us on 2 December, we lost a friend and a passionate European.  In his "Mémoires" he wrote that for him it was "a source of intense satisfaction [ ...] contribute to the construction of Europe." And its contribution is part of our reality: a European Parliament elected by universal suffrage; the creation in 1979 of the European Monetary System, which twenty years later gave birth to our single currency, the euro; the establishment of regular 'European Councils', such as the one that took place last week and which finally gave the green light to an important response to this crisis. His convictions have made him work tirelessly for a more democratic Europe, a Europe closer to its citizens, and led him to lead the Convention responsible for presenting the European Constitution. He believed a lot in a project that was as balanced as possible. And as Jean Monnet – who inspired him – observed, Europe seemed "une étape naturelle" to Valéry Giscard d'Estaing. That is also why it is only natural that the European Parliament should pay tribute to the President who was a Member of this Parliament from 1989 to 1993.  We will be meeting in this Chamber, here in Strasbourg, on 2 February, his birthday, to honour him in a ceremony attended by President Macron and other Heads of State or Government. Please join me for a minute's silence in memory of Valéry Giscard d'Estaing. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)  The time has come to maintain its fight and to work for a Europe that lives up to the expectations of our citizens. That is Parliament's commitment.  Last Saturday, five years ago, the Paris Agreement was signed. Since 2015, the European Union and many countries, parliaments and cities have declared a climate and environmental emergency. The citizens, especially our young people, have called for urgent action at global level.  Since then, we have imagined a more sustainable development model with environmental and social justice at its heart. The Green Deal is our new strategy, our new growth strategy and will be a turning point for decades to come. We want Europe to become the first climate-neutral continent in 2050. We want to be first in the class. Emission reduction targets are a measure of our ambition and, under European climate law, the European Parliament sees a 60 % reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 as the key to achieving our targets.  Through the Paris Agreement, European nations have committed themselves to playing a leading role in achieving the green transition. It is our responsibility, as a Parliament, to ensure that the Eu ropean Union continues to be a pioneer in the fight against climate change. The European Parliament will work to ensure a green transition and a just transition. But policies need resources. Important votes await us, and I am particularly pleased that Parliament will vote at this session on the multiannual financial framework and own resources, as well as on the rule of law regulation after the Council has unblocked these dossiers. This money, these instruments are extremely necessary for our citizens and our businesses. Parliament has been a decisive player from day one, because we wanted to reach the best possible agreement. This debate is not just about money, it is about the lives of Europeans. Therefore, we will remain vigilant in the implementation phase. In conclusion, I would also like to remind you at this time that we are about to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Dayton Agreement. While it was important for the time when he stopped the war, it is certainly time to look beyond this agreement and into the future. A quarter of a century later, the wounds of war are still present.  Only through genuine and sincere reconciliation can the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and their political leaders build an inclusive, prosperous and Europe-oriented society that offers a future to the younger generation. This is an important plenary session, it is a year that will enter the history books and we certainly do not want the consequences of this difficult year to stop us in our ambitions, in our projects and in our decisions, which will be so important, including next year, to ensure that the Union responds to the needs of our citizens.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: chairman budg. Mr President, I am satisfied that, in difficult circumstances, we were able to reach an agreement on the 2021 budget quite quickly.  It has indeed been a very special year with COVID-19, but also, of course, with very intense negotiations on the MFK and on the recovery plan. This has contributed to a great deal of pressure on the 2021 budget calendar. These circumstances have led to both Parliament and the Council and the Commission being required to adapt and work efficiently. I would therefore like to thank both Parliament's rapporteurs and Ambassador Clauss of the Council and Commissioner Hahn of the Commission for their remarkable adaptability and realism in these negotiations.  Parliament has shown itself to be constructive, but we remain vigilant. The transcripts of the agreements must be in accordance with the agreements. We have indicated both in the negotiations for the MFK and in the 2021 budget that we will continue to oppose misinterpretations.  Forward-looking programmes are being strengthened again, which is the message of the 2021 budget. The additional investments in, for example, trans-European transport networks and digital Europe meet the expectations of EU citizens. I am sure that the rapporteurs will certainly go into some other specific elements of the budgetary agreement. The focus on innovative and forward-looking programmes is also in line with the agreement on the multiannual budget.  Although I personally – and I really want this here – I think that this shift should have been more pronounced. Europe can really make a difference at global level, if it so wishes.  By thinking ahead, by focusing on education, on innovation, on research. Europe can distinguish itself here in areas where it can really offer added value. Above all, however, Europe would do itself a great service, because, of course, these expenditures and investments are so important for growth, job creation and competitiveness. After decades of – let me say – rather "classic" budgets, that shift in spending has been carefully deployed. As far as I am concerned, it should have been even more pronounced, but it is remarkable that this Parliament's negotiating team has had to fight to safeguard and strengthen forward-looking programmes. This means that there are still a number of stalled policy choices that continue to demand attention and resources. Just because we've always done it like this doesn't mean it should always be like this.   The European Union must constantly question itself and measure, objectively assess and adjust the efficiency of policy options where it is needed. I hope that in the next few years european policy actors – and certainly the Member States – will show courage to play real trump cards, for example, and not least in terms of research, development and infrastructure.  This brings me to a second observation. We can strengthen our innovative sectors by making the right policy choices and, of course, by linking the necessary budgets. However, it also calls for a comprehensive overall strategy. If, for example, we look at the position and attitude of the big tech companies, the conclusion is abundantly clear: the monopoly position of these giants is becoming increasingly problematic.  Honour who is honoured: Commissioner Vestager was one of the first to set a number of beacons and pushed boundaries, with varying degrees of success, but also with perseverance. For that, they and the Commission deserve all the credit for this. But the problem is clearly not off the table, far from it. When I read and see that the five major tech companies today have over EUR 500 billion – almost USD 600 billion – in cash, which is more than the GDP of my country, Belgium, where we are. That is huge, which is mind-boggling, and that proves that these companies – and this is, of course, euphemistically expressed – do not work in normal competitive conditions. Instead of staring blindly at how these big boys can be taxed – mind you, I have absolutely no problem with that, quite the contrary, although it sometimes seems like a battle for symbols and perception – this problem needs to be tackled on the ground. A digitaks is not going to change the landscape in that sector substantially. In fact, that levy will in any case be passed on to the user at least in part, directly or indirectly, to the consumer. I am convinced that there is an urgent need to develop levers to monitor the necessary balances in all innovative sectors. While we invest in our innovative start-ups and growers, they are in danger of being stifling by these giants because they are willingly driven into a trap.  That is cynical, it is undesirable, and that goes against the objectives of a future-oriented Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, I hope that we can join forces to work together towards a future-driven strategy for citizens and businesses.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, dear friends, there has been a lot of talk about the 'post-cancer world': the world after coronavirus. And if we are not able to radically change policy, I fear that the next world will be like the world before, but worse.  In 2020, we avoided collapse. Thanks to Angela Merkel, Emmanuel Macron and all the heads of state who supported the recovery plan. Thank you to all the diplomats, the commissioners, the senior officials who spent sleepless nights negotiating it. Without this plan, without the thousands of protected jobs, we would be very close to chaos. But we all know that nothing is settled. The mixture of the health crisis, the social crisis and the climate crisis can lead us very quickly to chaos. Everything remains to be done to build a new balance, a new model of prosperity. On Friday, all EU leaders agreed on a new target: to reduce CO2 emissions by 55% by 2030. Well done! But we all know that to achieve this result, everything remains to be done. If we take into account products imported from China, our CO2 emissions have never decreased. Our emissions, our carbon footprints have never decreased. So everything remains to be done. And 2020, despite the economic crisis, may be the worst year for CO2 developments, as forest fires have more than compensated for the decline in CO2 linked to the economic crisis.  My friends, in 2020, we avoided collapse. 2021 must be the year of renewal, a new beginning for Europe, a new social situation, a new ecological situation. And to finance this new situation, we need new financial resources. The European Commission itself says that to win the battle of climate and jobs, more than 600 billion euros of investment must be added each year. In its report voted on 13 November, Parliament provides concrete solutions to find the $600 billion, including five new own resources. He points out that the financial transaction tax alone can bring in $57 billion a year, despite Brexit and the economic crisis. $57 billion is more than the other four resources together. And to get out of the unanimity rule that blocks negotiations, Parliament calls for the immediate resumption of enhanced cooperation with a group of pioneering countries. The good news is that in the budget agreement that was approved by the 27 Member States on Thursday, the European Commission joins Parliament's proposal. It reiterates that negotiations with a group of pioneering countries on the financial transaction tax can be restarted, in enhanced cooperation, and that this negotiation can be completed by 2022. The Commission says that if the negotiations are completed by 2022, it will propose to make this financial transaction tax a clean resource for the whole of the Union. The Commission joins Parliament's proposals to unblock the negotiations. This time, if a country wants to block the negotiation, it will not be able to. No need for unanimity. And if the speculation tax at the same time allows the common debt of "Next Generation EU" to be repaid and the climate and employment plan financed, whoever blocks the negotiation will have to explain to his constituents that he would rather lower pensions or health spending than tax traders a little.  My friends, in 2021, Europe needs a historic turning point. In conscience, I think the 2021 budget is good, but it is not up to the challenge. I have said this for several months before you, in conscience: if there is not an additional $50 billion each year for the budget, I will not be able to vote for it. I will not vote against either, I will abstain. This is the first time in the history of Parliament that a budget has been supported by six groups, and I thank them. I believe that in the coming months, together with Angela Merkel, with Antonio Costa, we will be able to create a new Union. In 1950, it took Schuman and Adenauer two weeks to create the European Coal and Steel Community. I hope that in the next six months we will be creating the Union for Health, Climate and Employment. A new Union financed by a tax on speculation.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today I am satisfied. Satisfied with the knowledge that European values have not been chipped to get Poland and Hungary vetoed the next multi-year financial framework. It is also pleased to see that all the EU institutions have carried high the European values of solidarity and responsibility. Finally, satisfied to see that all these months spent negotiating the first budget of this new budget cycle will enable the Union to start, from 1 January next, in optimal conditions to ensure recovery. This is the victory of a united European Parliament. It is the victory of a Europe that acts, listens to its citizens and does not want to leave anyone at the edge of the road. As I have said on many occasions, the budget is much more than numbers: they are political choices. These are not expenditures: they are investments in projects and programmes that serve citizens, in the service of a greener, more social, fairer Europe, which is concerned with sustainable economic development.  In this negotiation, we have therefore decided to strengthen some of the flagship programmes such as health, youth, digital and its artificial intelligence component, justice and the fight against violence against women, the environment and climate issues, transport infrastructure and research. We have also paid particular attention to the sectors most affected by the crisis, such as SMEs and tourism, in order to preserve workers and promote the creation of sustainable jobs. We have called for a strong and operational European Public Prosecutor's Office, capable of fully carrying out its tasks to protect the European budget. We also wanted, in these hectic times, to provide support to the younger generations, because the best investment we can make to avoid a generation COVID-19 is to invest in our youth.  The 2021 European budget also includes the budget of our institutions - Parliament and other European institutions. In this regard, it balances the economies of our health crisis-disrupted way of operating with the need to operate our institutions effectively. Colleagues, our institutions have shown courage, preferring creativity and ingenuity to business as usual for a massive, sustainable recovery. Europe will indeed be present, mobilising from next year considerable investments to meet the most urgent economic and social needs, stimulate a sustainable recovery, respectful of the climate and environmental issues, preserve jobs and create new ones.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by underlining how impressed I am that, despite the persistent uncertainty that clouded the budget negotiations, we were able to send a forceful signal that the European Union can stand together for progress and prosperity. Hence, I would like to congratulate the negotiators, in particular the two rapporteurs, Mr Larrouturou and Mr Chastel, and the German Presidency, who were forcefully and well versed in the art of the compromise and made it finally possible. The agreement for 2021 is a forward—looking compromise, fully in line with the larger framework of the long-term budget for 2021 to 2027 and Next Generation EU, which will provide an unprecedented EUR 1.8 trillion budget to help rebuild a post—COVID—19 Europe. The 2021 budget agreement not only fully respects the MFF political agreement but also reflects both the Parliament and Council positions fairly. This budget will allow the Union to mobilise significant funds for a continued EU response to the coronavirus pandemic and its consequences, to kick—start a sustainable recovery and to protect and create jobs. It ensures that we are able to invest in the future to achieve a greener, more digital and, finally, more resilient Europe. I will now briefly run through the main elements of our agreement. Overall commitments will be EUR 164 billion and the overall level of payment appropriations will be EUR 166 billion. It’s important that we also preserve flexibility in next year’s budget. Since the uncertainty doesn’t end at the end of this year, we can be sure that we will also need the flexibility next year. This budget agreement ensures that we have that room for manoeuvre to face whatever awaits us in 2021. The agreement includes the entire package of pilot projects and preparatory actions proposed by the Parliament, amounting to EUR 72 million. It maintains our ability to fully finance the funding costs of Next Generation EU whilst reinforcing shared priorities, partially by reallocating and partially by making additional money available from the unallocated margins of the MFF. Overall, we agreed to reinforce the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) for Transport, EUR 60 million, plus EUR 60 million in Digital Europe, plus EUR 26 million, which will benefit our green and digital transitions and our economic recovery alike. Additionally, we reconfirm our commitment to a greener Europe by the substantive reinforcement of the LIFE programme: an additional EUR 42 million. We will strengthen the Justice Programme, plus EUR 3 million in the Rights and Values Programme, plus EUR 7 million. We also agreed to further reinforce the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, thus strengthening the Union’s ability to investigate, prosecute and bring to justice crimes against the EU budget, such as fraud and corruption, and we hope it can finally become operational soon. We further agreed to strengthen the Fundamental Rights Agency, the European Institute for Gender Equality, Eurojust and eu-LISA. On the external policy side, we reinforced the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI) and we increased our strategic communications capacity, as well as humanitarian aid. Beyond the bare finances, five statements have been added. These highlight, amongst others, the priority to tackle child poverty and the urgent need to tackle the impact of the COVID—19 crisis, with particular attention to sectors that are severely hit by the crisis, such as tourism and SMEs, and the people that are the most affected by the crisis, such as children and young people. Additionally, we will also make the research commitment available again to the benefit of the new Horizon Europe programme. Therefore, the famous Article 50.3 of the financial regulations has been implemented, in line with the MFF agreement. Let me close by underlining once again how positive a signal this agreement and the agreement on the long-term budget are. They show the Union’s ability to serve European citizens. So I am grateful for the compromise and the extra mile that all of you went to make this possible, and that we managed, may I say, to arrive at an agreement three days before the deadline. That could become a blueprint for the future, and I hope that this is not only a promise, but it could be repeated next year.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Dear Vice-Presidents, in the most difficult moments for Europe, at a time of deep uncertainty and in the run-up to Christmas that will be different from previous ones, it is encouraging that an agreement has been reached on the multiannual financial framework and the European recovery package.  In this context, the first annual budget since the beginning of the pandemic and the first budget without the UK will be an important and necessary step towards Europe's recovery. We are expected to have concrete solidarity towards the most affected countries, economic sectors, but also generations. Unfortunately, it seems that young people will once again be most affected by the economic crisis.  That is why new lost years must not be allowed for generations of young Europeans and this was one of the principles we were guided by in drawing up this budget.  Recovery will only be possible with dynamic SMEs, which are the engine of the European economy, as well as with further investments in the modernisation of Europe - by investing in health, digitalisation and infrastructure.  In this unprecedented crisis, health and economic crisis, we must continue to transform our economies, but this is not possible without a smart, quality use of European funds, without using the European budget, and therefore I congratulate everyone on a successful agreement for the 2021 budget.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – (the beginning of the intervention was not done at the microphone) ... Sustainable. The European Parliament wanted a budget that would create the prerequisites for a better future for all European citizens, but many of the right-wing leaders of the Member States did not want this. The Council proposed a budget option without ambition, and even though we managed to achieve significant increases in the last negotiations, the final version could have looked better. The more than EUR 160 billion must generate growth and jobs. The European Parliament - and this was the priority of our political group and myself as a member of the Committee on Budgets in the European Parliament - has achieved significant increases for the new European Programme for Health, Youth and Education, as well as for research, digitisation, the environment, agriculture, humanitarian aid and infrastructure. For a strong Europe, we must allocate the resources we need at European level. Our priority must be for European funds to reach the beneficiary as soon as possible.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we have all welcomed the lifting of the Hungarian and Polish vetoes with relief. This positive outcome will allow us to avoid starting 2021 with a crisis budget, a budget that would not have allowed us to finance our new policies, our new priorities. So, dear friends, in less than three weeks we will start a new cycle for Europe: that of Europe of defence, that of Europe of health, that of green Europe and, hence, that of Europe which does not sell its values. 2021 will also be the year of the introduction of the first of a new set of own resources, the 'plastic contribution'. The first in 32 years. We owe this to the Commission's proposal, Commissioner, but also to pressure from the European Parliament. Without that, I doubt we would have made progress on the subject. These are collective victories, and we must stress that. One last point, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I note that the annual budget was passed without difficulty. That's great. But the multi-year budget once again rolled out the red carpet to national haggling and selfishness, because it was passed unanimously. A true path of the cross to find the common interest. So I ask this question: when is the end of unanimity in Europe? The psychodramas we undergo every seven years are no longer bearable! Tomorrow, the conference for the future of Europe must put an end to this issue.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Hahn, for the work she has said on how to do this. I congratulate you on a successfully negotiated 2021 budget. You know, however, that the budget rests on a very fragile foundation. However, since it is the first in the new MFF and among the new challenges of the reconstruction plan, it would be important that it is reliable and can also be carried out in a stable manner. However, I have my doubts about this, even after the committee meeting this afternoon. After the overall package had already been voted on in July, it was amended at the instigation of Parliament at the beginning of November so that no party clearly knew what was now in place. Therefore, after last week's summit, everyone was able to declare themselves the winner. There is something wrong with that. How can this be explained? I am afraid that the negotiations for the overall package did not play with open cards. Yet it is one of our Christian values – and this is especially true in the present Advent season – that in preparation for the coming of the world judge, we "speak truth with our neighbour". Speaking truth is obviously the precondition of the prophet Zechariah, whom I have just quoted, that we can sing loudly and joyfully with the daughter of Zion the king's entry. I wish we had paid more attention to this in the negotiations, and then the budget was based on a more stable basis. Nevertheless, I wish you a contemplative Advent and a graceful Christmas season.

name: David CORMAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this is where we are: a 2021 budget which has made many advances - an additional EUR 180 million compared to the previous one. It is quite rare to see such an increase, particularly on environmental issues - the LIFE programme, the European Environment Agency - but also on transport. And also on an important subject: the issue of gender equality.  But, as we know, this first budget 2021 is the first in a new budget cycle. And on that point, there are still gaps that are too great in relation to the urgency to act that is ours. While the new stated target of a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 is an unprecedented effort, it is still largely insufficient. In this race of speed that is ours in relation to the climatic disorders, the fall of biodiversity, the devastation caused by our so-called "development" model, we must go harder and we have to go much faster.  From this point of view, it must be said at some point that this Parliament and the European Union can no longer accept to be the toy of conflicting interests of States and the Council, particularly in budgetary matters. If we want a federal Europe, a powerful Europe, a Europe that weighs in the concert of the world, we must have fiscal autonomy, budgetary independence. And that is the question of reclaiming their own resources. Certainly, from 2021, there will be the plastic contribution. But that is nothing compared to the issue of charging those who today are exempt from tax. It is the carbon tax at the borders, it is the tax on speculation and on financial transactions, it is the tax on the digital giants, this is the great work that awaits us if we want to have the means of our ambitions and to be able to finally lead the ecological and social transition that our continent needs.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Following Thursday's Agreement of the European Council, we are closer to European solidarity. It's obviously a great success. In 2021, we will have EUR 185 million more than projected in the draft budget. This money will be used for transport, humanitarian aid, digital Europe, etc. These are good news. I therefore hope that all these actions will continue accordingly.  However, I have concerns that today there was a lawyer in the Commission who simply took all the findings of last Thursday in brackets. It turns out that it is not known – he spoke on behalf of a very important institution, that lawyer – what was agreed at the European Council and what the European Commission may have. There has even been a statement that if the European Commission works badly, the European Parliament will revoke it. Let us not go in this direction. The three institutions of the European Union must cooperate, not wage war. We must act together, we must build this solidarity. The language that was used today just after the success of that week is not a good language. This is a bad signal, because the Member States will again start to fear that something is threatening them. Let us not go down this path, let us build European solidarity, let us rejoice in the agreement.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the European Parliament, united and with great effort, has achieved considerable improvements both in the 2021 budget, amounting to around EUR 150 million, and in the multiannual budget, EUR 16 billion more. But the improvements we have achieved are far from the objectives we have set and especially from the needs of the times, because our countries, our societies are being tested by a fierce second wave of the pandemic with a hundred deaths, because we have a very great recession and a dangerous increase in social inequalities with the new generation and the socially weaker first victims.  That is why, despite the steps we have taken in the European Parliament, there is no justification for any celebration. We need a more ambitious budget to tackle public health problems and the consequences of the pandemic, to have a stronger economic recovery, to strengthen the social state, to achieve more ambitious targets in tackling the climate crisis and in the digital transition. That is why the European Parliament should continue to be assertive, and I note with satisfaction that our main rapporteur, Pierre Larrouturou, consistent with this line, has said that he will choose to vote abstention in the 2021 budget.

name: Angelika WINZIG
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The 2021 budget is special for a number of reasons, because the negotiations on this were not only overshadowed by the Corona pandemic, but also by the grand package of linking the multiannual financial framework, new own resources, the building fund and the rule of law. I would like to thank all my colleagues very much for their good cooperation.  With a budget of EUR 164 billion, comparable to Austria's general government budget, it is important to achieve an efficient use of funds. Research, innovation, transport, digitalisation and energy are at the heart of our budget, because they secure us a competitive future. We must not make the mistake of putting the horse upside down. We must not forget one thing: The Green Deal cannot fly without digitalisation and innovation.  In addition to the right focus, it is, of course, important to me how to handle our citizens' taxpayers' money carefully. I am glad that we have found a very sensible solution to the administrative expenditure of the ten institutions. Many thanks to Commissioner Hahn, to the German Presidency, for the fact that we have managed to bring the budget into force in good time, because that guarantees our citizens security and support.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, the 2021 budget opens a new cycle for cohesion policies, which are more environmentally friendly, as intended, but it also represents a new cycle of European programmes. The results of the 21-27 MFF negotiation, many of my family's s&D political claims, are already shaped in the 2021 budget. With the crisis we are witnessing a devastated cultural sector. That is why the funding of the Creative Europe Programme has increased. With the crisis we have seen the weakening of democracies in some Member States. That is why the funding of the Rights and Values Program has increased. But also the transport sector, Life, Justice, Digital Europe, Humanitarian Aid or NDICI, key sectors for economic and social recovery, but also for the European Union to commit itself in the global context, in a multipolar world, contributing to climate objectives or to the enhancement of the European Union's geostrategic capacity.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, colleagues, first of all I am quite thankful that we now speak from the lectern so we can actually see each other when we speak. I would like to thank Pierre Larrouturou and Olivier Chastel for the tough and very good negotiations. I think the outcome is a greener and more digital budget. While I’m happy with the overall agreement, I’m concerned that the Polish and Hungarian governments caused such massive disruption to our negotiations. I’ve been in this Parliament for more or less 18 months and I’ve gone through negotiations of two annual budgets, the MFF programmes and currently the EU’s recovery programme. I still consider myself a newbie but I do want to share three hard lessons learned with you. First of all, multilateralism does work. We did find an agreement and we did find a good agreement on this budget. Second, our EU decision-making is still deeply flawed. We allow individual governments to outright blackmail this Union, holding the wellbeing of all EU citizens to ransom for their own, at times, personal financial benefit. And third, too often we cave in to this blackmailing and every time we compromise in the direction of these blackmailers. We show European citizens that in this Union sometimes money trumps values. Last week’s European Council conclusions are a perfect example of this phenomenon. I think we should never trade principles over money or values over power, and I would really urge the von der Leyen Commission to set the record straight in this direction.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I would like to express my joy at the adoption of the multiannual budget and the recovery plan. All Member States should be pleased with this. We are all happy because, in fact, great financial resources are foreseen for the next seven years.  On the other hand, I am astonded to know that the biggest political groups in the European Parliament are trying to play something in this situation. They want these measures to somehow depend on the rule of law, which is very precisely set out in the Council conclusions. It would be good for the European Commission to take these conclusions for granted and try to implement them. The European Parliament and individual Member States should not argue with the European Council on this matter. This is difficult for me to accept, and I hope that we will cooperate on this issue and we will want to use EU money to make the European Union happen.... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, 2021 will have to be a year of recovery, a year of recovery and also a year of hope, a year in which resilience also reemerges, and the 2021 budget will make a very important contribution to this objective: a budget that has a high added value. We should tell all Europeans that the European Union budget accounts for only about 1% of GDP. It is a budget where more than 93% is for investment and, in Member States such as mine, Portugal, is responsible for more than 80% of public investment. A budget that helps competitiveness, productivity, meet environmental targets. A budget that also helps to include. A budget, therefore, which is internally supportive, but also helps other countries and developing countries. A budget that has a component of humanitarian aid and external solidarity that is also important. It is essential that, with this budget, with a recovery fund now and there are still many billions of euros left to implement from the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, member states use these resources well. Using resources well means knowing what you want to do, and then using it to promote not only convergence, but also territorial cohesion, economic cohesion and social cohesion.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, the rule of law agreement is good news for the Union, as it has managed to avoid a political crisis in difficult times. However, the introduction of value for money as a condition for the absorption of European funds has long been lacking in the creation of the budget. The agreement has almost failed on the condition of compliance with the rule of law, but there has been no heated debate in the Council or parliament to date on whether European money is being used effectively by the Member States. I therefore call on the Commission to develop more precise impact clauses and to use better result indicators. It is only with relevant evaluations and data that we will be able to minimise waste of taxpayers' resources and allocate resources to programmes with the highest added value. Nice rest of the evening from Bratislava.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, one of the things Covid has been able to do is actually motivate leaders to reach an agreement on the European budget quickly, of course, once the European Parliament has done its job quite in time, it has prepared its position in just in time. This, of course, happens with the hard work of the rapporteurs, of the negotiating team, of which I am proud and happy to be a part. Here we should thank the German Presidency for its efforts to adopt this budget in time and open the door to the Multiannual Financial Framework.  The European budget is at supranational level, but in fact there is a lot of local expression. I will give you, for example, my country, the country I know best. Cohesion Policy alone can have around a billion and a half euros and another half a billion euros for rural development; this is a resource that helps these more backward regions to develop and catch up with others in Europe. Of course, I am happy that such an agreement was reached in time, because in these difficult and difficult times people need to see politicians and institutions working together, not those who argue.  I therefore thank everyone for reaching an agreement and I am pleased that from 1 January the European Budget will be available to all beneficiaries, citizens and businesses in Europe.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Inspired by the voices unfortunately falling from here, I would like to begin my speech with words of special thanks and appreciation to the two Prime Ministers, Viktor Orban and Mateusz Morawiecki, who, contrary to such voices and even in order to abandon the so-called unanimity, conducted these negotiations in such a way that an agreement was reached.  The European Union is based on treaties, and the treaties state that each of the countries that make it has the same value and dignity, whether it be Malta – with all due respect and sympathy for this beautiful country – or Germany or France. The European Union cannot rely on the terror of political correctness only on the European left. And that we are entering the new year, I would like to remind you that in Europe we count the years since the birth of Jesus Christ. Europe will be either Christian or not at all.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Thank you for this debate and the really strong support for next year's budget. I believe that with next year's budget – embedded in the multiannual financial framework – we now have a solid basis for the next few years in order to help Europe, European citizens and European entrepreneurs emerge stronger from this crisis, to be even more competitive in the future and to play a real role at global level. I can only thank everyone for this hard work; it has not, in fact, been easy in recent months. It took the usual European drama that a reasonable compromise could be reached at the almost last minute – but certainly expected – on all expenses. What is crucial now is implementation, implementation, implementation! The financial framework has been set aside, but now we really need to make use of these opportunities! Why am I saying this? The Commission has taken more than 500 decisions in the last few months since March on the subject of state aid in the order of EUR 3 000 billion, and so far we have only had the exploitation of these possibilities in the order of just over 15% in the individual Member States. So what is crucial now is that the opportunities that have been and are being made available are also being used appropriately in the Member States, so that we can actually see this rapid and strong recovery of the European Union.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has There are 50 million people living in the EU who are members of a minority. In addition to the 24 official languages, we have over 60 regional and minority languages. The members of these minorities are an integral part of Europe's cultural diversity. As a German Sinto, I am one of those 50 million. Dealing with minorities is a measure of the freedom and democracy of our society. The best guarantee for the free development of minorities is the establishment of their rights. It is about the rights as citizens of the EU, it is about the free development of cultural rights and the protection of their language. But it is precisely this protection that is patchy in the EU, as there are no common EU minimum standards or a legal framework that ensures the protection and promotion of minorities. The Minority SafePack initiative and its more than one million supporters want to improve this situation. Key issues are simplified access to cultural production and media in one's own language, the promotion of linguistic diversity and participation in support programmes in the cultural sector.  Last but not least, the decisive fight against statelessness is an important element, which still exists as a phenomenon in Europe and affects people with a Romani background in particular. It is unacceptable for people to be denied state protection and equal participation because of administrative harassment or racist reservations. In addition, we in the EU are constantly seeing cases of segregation, racism, hate speech and xenophobia against ethnic minorities. Discrimination takes place in education, in work or in access to the social system. In the Corona pandemic, this situation has worsened and minorities have been blamed for the spread of the virus. This dimension must also be taken into account when we talk about minority rights, because in a climate of fear and stigma, the unhindered exercise of cultural and civil rights is hardly conceivable. As representatives of European societies, we have a responsibility to work for the rights and equal participation of all people in the EU. I therefore hope that this important citizens' initiative will receive broad support in this House. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 15 October I had the honour to co-chair a parliamentary session of the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs, together with the Committee on Petitions, in which we welcomed a citizen initiative, which is a right referred to in Article 11 of the Treaty on European Union, exactly to promote citizen participation in the european decision-making process. This European Parliament has no deficit of democratic legitimacy. It is the only directly elective institution of the Union's architecture. It has no competition deficit. It is a fully legislative Parliament, also in the field of fundamental rights, but it is a Parliament which has difficulties , let us say this , in connecting with the citizenship we represent and, therefore, here we find an initiative that has managed to overcome all the difficulties in which dozens of others have been directed who have tried, but have failed to reach this House.  There are at least seventy citizen initiatives that have been launched, but here we find one – one of which has one hand – that has managed to gather no less than 1 300 000 signatures, not in seven Member States – a quarter, article 11 of the Treaty on European Union – but eleven. Moreover, it does so in a matter which calls for the Commission's action because it is consistent with European values, with the value of minority protection, enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. And we have said many times that the European idea of democracy is neither confined to the rule of the majority, but requires the protection of minorities in accordance with the rule of law. And here we find the protection of cultural and linguistic minorities, consistent with the European Charter of Regional or Minority Languages, adopted by the Council of Europe, which aims to send the Commission to take those measures, legal or legal acts, which are required to do so in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity , of proportionality, but above all of the prohibition of discrimination, which is a fundamental right enshrined in Articles 21 and 22 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We therefore have a great option to do this work, and I am happy to welcome this citizen initiative, which makes sense, which undoubtedly affects competences which are the responsibility of the Member States but which can receive added value from the European decision-making process. And that is what I hope will happen from now on with an observatory, with a centre for the promotion of linguistic diversity, which will watch over the prohibition of hate speech against linguistic minorities and therefore offer added value to the recognition of the status that linguistic diversity deserves in the European Union.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Committee on Petitions. – Madam President, according to the rules, the Committee on Petitions is automatically associated when a Citizens’ Initiative is published. Why so? Because our committee is a bridge between people and the European institutions. We receive individual petitions. We receive collective petitions, some of them signed by thousands or hundreds of thousands, but, of course, the European Citizens’ Initiative signed by one million people from many Member States is in the first round, in the first column, of that bridge. And of course the Minority SafePack is a special column since it had to go over the bridge two times. First it was thrown out, then it had to go to the European Court of Justice and is now reaching the institutions. And the Minority SafePack discussion was very active and this initiative received the support of the majority of those participating in the hearings two months ago. Therefore, Commissioner, we are waiting for very concrete steps from your side. We want you to legislate just on behalf of the Commission. We have no right to disappoint the 1.2 million people who signed this petition. And a few words about a particular group of signatories from my small state, Latvia: not all of those who wanted to send a petition could do it, since among minorities one quarter are those stateless non-citizens who have no rights to sign, who have no rights to take part in any elections and are deprived of many rights. I am very happy that one of the nine items included in this initiative is approximating equality for stateless minorities like the Roma. The solution for realising this proposal could be the following: the Member State makes a declaration that a person who does not hold the nationality of any country, but who resides in that Member State and holds a travel document issued by that Member State is to be in possession of the same rights that EU law grants to EU citizens. When amending the visa regulations in 2006, by my proposal, just these EU residents defined by this formula were exempted from the visa requirements. But it was, to my regret, the only essential approximation of the rights of stateless citizens. Now it is time to go further and to grant them the rights that EU citizens in all Member States other than their own have – the right to vote in local and European elections, the right to work, etc. So, such a good approach can be initiated by the Commission.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the European Parliament for having organised, in these challenging COVID—19 times, a successful public hearing on the European Citizens’ Initiative ‘Minority SafePack’ early in October. This allowed the organisers to present the initiative and the different Members to express their views.  Today’s plenary debate provides another opportunity to listen carefully to the contributions and interventions from various Members. This will further deepen our joint understanding of the different political considerations in support of the various proposals covered by these initiatives.  Today’s plenary debate on this initiative confirms that the European Citizens’ Initiative instrument offers a unique tool for citizens to engage in direct participatory democracy. Maybe even more important, it demonstrates that it is an agenda—setting tool for policy shaping at Union level. The Minority SafePack initiative is not the last initiative to have successfully collected the required one million signatures and to have been submitted to the Commission for examination. In October, the Commission received a sixth successful initiative called ‘End the Cage Age’.  At this point in time I am not able to go into the details of the Commission reply to the organisers of the Minority SafePack initiative. Today, we will listen to you and I will carefully reflect on the resolution once adopted. The exchange of views today will inspire the ongoing reflection process of the Commission. We will present our general conclusions, as well as the action that we intend to take, in a communication planned for January next year. In that respect I wish a further fruitful discussion.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Europe is the sum of its cultures, traditions and history. I myself come from a country where up to five different official languages coexist, all of them languages of Spain. Anyone who sees a problem in this rich variety is that they do not understand what the European Union is.  With this citizen initiative, Parliament endorses the duty to protect those who are discriminated against for speaking a language or not doing so; endorses rejection of those who use languages as an instrument of confrontation and hatred; says that the promotion of regional languages must always be done in compliance with the fundamental rights of all people.  Today, in Europe, there are those who use a language, a culture, not to educate, but to imagine sectarian and exclusionary communities. This is how the virus of nationalism manifests itself, which has brought so much misfortune to our continent.  I am proud to belong to a country that protects its linguistic wealth through the Constitution. With this Resolution, we celebrate the cultural diversity of our continent and commit ourselves to its protection. Let us not let nationalists take away the success of being European.

name: Hannes HEIDE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her 1.2 million people– we have heard it – have signed the European Citizens' Initiative and advocated the protection and promotion of cultural and linguistic diversity. They have succeeded in making it clear that, in addition to the 24 official languages of the Union, there are more than 60 regional and minority languages – 40 million citizens of the European Union are affected. However, this citizens' initiative will only be really successful if the resolution we are debating today is followed by concrete measures and actions.  A language is alive when it is spoken, and this requires educational institutions such as schools, such as kindergartens and, above all, native language teaching. Opportunities for media use such as books, newspapers, in films, on the stage or in television broadcasts are also necessary. However, this will not be possible without support from European Union support programmes.  In Austria, where the Commissioner comes from and where I come from, the protection of minorities is of particular importance. Minority rights are enshrined in the State Treaty, and yet their enforcement has also been linked to conflict. And Austria, on the other hand, has fought for the rights of German-speaking South Tyroleans.  And therefore my conclusion: what we are asking for an ethnic group connected to us in another country should be at least as self-evident for ethnic groups in their own country. In this way, we can help to prevent and end conflicts and violence, and that is one of the founding ideas of the European Union. We may come from different cultures and countries and speak different languages, but we should use a common language, that of our common values and the rule of law that underpins this European Union. We should oppose discrimination, and in this sense I support the concerns of this initiative and, above all, its objective of ensrising the rights of minorities in Union law.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first I would like to congratulate all the people behind the Minority SafePack initiative on its success. This initiative received over one million signatures from Europeans across the Europe Union and is the fifth most successful European Citizens’ Initiative to date. The ECI instrument gives European citizens the unique opportunity to achieve an active part in the political process. The subject of this initiative is close to the heart of Renew Europe and to me personally. I am of Moroccan descent but was born and raised in Friesland, a province in the north of the Netherlands with its own identity and language. Being Frisian means being proud of the history and cultural heritage of this part of the Netherlands. Next to Dutch, I also learned the Frisian language at school, and it is important that we keep teaching it to preserve this part of our cultural wealth. And I believe it’s one of the core values of our Union that we have respect for cultural and linguistic diversity and protect the rights of minorities in the EU. More than 50 million Europeans belong to traditional minorities and language groups. It’s our duty as the European Union to play an active role in protecting and promoting, and celebrating the diversity in, traditions and languages throughout the European Union. So Commissioner, let me ask you: how will you give a follow-up to this initiative and its proposals? How are you going to promote, protect and celebrate the cultural and linguistic diversity of our Union? I hope we as the European Parliament will be behind this initiative and give full support to the one million signatures and all European citizens belonging to a traditional or language minority. And allow me, Madam President, to say: Tige Tank! That means: thank you very much.

name: Virginie JORON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am here in Strasbourg to discuss the proposals of the European Minority Rescue Plan initiative, a plan which, unfortunately, fails to define the term 'national minority'.  Elected in Alsace, I can easily know how important it is for the Alsatians to preserve their historical speaking. This is reflected in many French regions - Brittany or Corsica, to name but a few - which contribute to France's cultural and heritage wealth, in the same way as in other European countries.  If in France we attach particular importance to the French language, it is because we know how powerful it is of assimilation and national cohesion. Nations have based themselves on a melting pot of local, multiple and linguistic cultures, which are desirable to be preserved. But we should not confuse entrenched culture to preserve with imported culture. Bengali communities in Ireland or Iraq in Sweden should not be considered national minorities. Nor should these proposals fall into the same way as President Macron, who wants to introduce the Arabic language in primary school. We are Europeans, we are Europe, and our role must be to preserve and promote European cultures.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! More than 1 million Europeans are sending a very clear signal to the European Parliament and the Commission. Do more to protect minorities. Minority policy is a European task. The Fries, the Sinsis, the Roma, the Basques or the Danish minority in South Schleswig, minorities are found in many models. More than 50 million Europeans belong to a national minority or speak a minority language. Being able to be yourself and be able to speak one's own language is a human right. Many European minorities have come a long way, others will have to fight for basic rights in relation to language, education or social services. This is particularly true for the citizens of many Eastern EU states. Minority policy is a common European task. We have a responsibility. We need European legislation and a European Commission that interferes when minorities are discriminated against. Our Green EFA Group fully supports each of the 9 different and concrete proposals from the Minority Safe Pack initiative. With our Parliament's discussion, we are sending a very strong signal to the European Commission. Dear Ursula Von der Leyen, dear Johannes Hahn, now it is your turn, fight alongside the EUROPEAN Parliament for minority rights and put forward concrete legislative proposals!

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, indeed the promotion of European linguistic and cultural diversity raised by the Minority SafePack is a noble aim. At the same time, when carrying out the linguistic diversity preservation strategy, we need to look at various aspects, including the risk factors for language survival, as well as the states’ abilities to strengthen their culture and information spaces. Similarly, the constitutional, historical and geopolitical aspects of each Member State have to be respected and taken into account. By promoting multilingualism throughout Europe we have to see the whole picture of the world languages, promotion instruments for ensuring linguistic plurality also need to support those official EU languages which have a relatively small, and falling, number of speakers. We cannot create a situation whereby promotion of a certain minority language within a country leads to the endangerment of the official state language or comes at the expense of other minority languages. What is more, let us not be blind and deaf to attempts by certain third countries to use the minority-language issue as a propaganda tool to implicitly intervene in the internal affairs of the EU Member States and spread disinformation, thus trying to undermine societal cohesion or cause friction within the EU.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I too would like to compliment the citizens who championed this initiative. It’s always difficult to get to this stage, but not only did they have the normal battle, they also had to go to the European Court of Justice in order to be heard because the Commission declared that their petition was not valid. So I salute them and I salute the coordinator of the resolution who, I have to say, I thought did a better job on the initial resolution than the one we have before us here today. I am heartened to hear the strong comments by colleagues, because it’s not good enough just to talk about statelessness. We need to back the call in the initiative – and the original wording did that – that we need to amend EU legislation to guarantee equal treatment of stateless persons and citizens across the Union. Without this, stateless Roma in Europe and EU candidate countries, really without a nationality, have no access to areas like education, health care, employment and so on. We need to resource the fact that endangered languages need to be kept alive. They need to be funded, planned, and we need positive discrimination in that. So I really hope that the Commission hears the loud voice of this Parliament, but more important, the voice of the citizens who got us here.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, by adopting a strong resolution concerning the Minority SafePack Initiative, the European Parliament as co-legislator can finally – with considerable delay – establish a legal framework to protect the largest minority across Europe: indigenous minorities exceeding 60 million people in total. And we can do that with the support and at the behest of over one million of our citizens that signed the European Citizens’ Initiative, the most democratic and powerful instrument our community has developed. I am convinced that peace and stability in post-war Europe is not only due to the reconciliation of European nation states, but also to a reconciliation between the majority and indigenous minorities within our nation states. Territorial integrity of modern states is protected by political convention and international law. Now it is our duty to legislate to safeguard each and every minority, regardless of where they reside, and grant them rights – a key to their prosperity and our civilisation’s stability. Therefore, I implore you, all my colleagues, regardless of which political groups you represent, to support this historic initiative.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support More than one million to 100,000 citizens have signed up to the Minority SafePack initiative, and their voices and expectations must be heard by the committee. They are calling for a halt to the loss of population and language. For some of my fellow Members, this is a sensitive subject. Of course it is, because there are Member States where national minorities are protected and valued, but in some countries they are not even recognised, in others the state does not comply with existing minority protection laws. The Luxembourg court has clearly stated that the Union has the opportunity to adopt supporting measures on this subject. The European Commission has demonstrated that it can act on the values of the Treaties by developing a strategy for the protection of other minorities. The Minority SafePack initiative will do the same for indigenous national and linguistic minorities. Let us protect our common European legacy. I call on the committee to take a bold step in legislation at the citizens' motion and following a decision of parliament, and good governance and consistency require it. Thank you.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The protection of minorities and the protection of their rights, in particular their linguistic and cultural identity, are fundamental values of the EU. The citizens' initiative Minority SafePack rightly draws attention to the fact that there is still room for improvement in the EU at times. It unites more than a million Europeans behind them, and they have joined forces and formulated a catalogue of demands for the European Commission – that is called political participation, and we should appreciate that in itself! However, the Minority SafePack also deserves our support in terms of content, because the citizens' initiative is at the heart of the European Union. What makes the European Union exceptional in the first place is not the common internal market, but linguistic and cultural diversity. This EU would be many times poorer without these minorities. If we care about respect for our cultural and linguistic diversity, for the preservation of our motto 'united in diversity', then we should also be concerned about the protection of minorities. In this sense, we should support this joint resolution by a large majority, thereby sending a strong signal to the European Commission. It should present concrete measures and legal acts to promote and strengthen the rights of minorities, in particular as regards language learning, including minority languages, as well as the cultural participation of minorities. In this context, it is no wonder that the demand for improved cross-border access to online media libraries is re-emerging. During the last parliamentary term, we failed to make changes to the existing legal framework to help linguistic minorities access culture and information in their own language. There is an urgent need for improvements here.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We often say that we are all equal as citizens of the European Union, but unfortunately the daily experience of many is that they are more equal than equals. The sad reality is that many national and ethnic minorities in Europe are now at a disadvantage compared to mainstream citizens. Hungarians abroad, for example, have been in this situation for generations. And the equalisation of the chances of the Roma has been put off or even curbed by certain governments for decades. My fellow Members, I ask you to listen to the voice of European citizens and to raise the protection of minorities to European level. I ask you not only to talk about it, but also to achieve equality, because the way in which we treat our minorities is a certificate of the state of democracy in Europe. So I'm asking you to act. Thank you very much.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Under Article 5 of the EU Treaty, the EU may act only within the limits of its contractual competences in accordance with the principle of limited individual authorisation. All competences not delegated to the Union remain with the Member States.  Objectives in Article 2 alone are not an authorisation to act under Article 5. And under Article 11(4), the EU cannot implement a citizens' initiative if it is not authorised under Article 5. In short, the protection of minorities is not a matter for the EU, but for the Member States. At most, article 167 encourages the EU's cooperation in terms of cultural policy. And why are we still debating EU measures to protect minorities? Because many here believe that the EU has an interest in dissolving national communities and majorities into a sea of minorities. And if you have dissolved the sense of community and broken down each individual like Robert Musil's "Man Without Characteristics" into his nine or twelve identities, what do you do with your people with too much identity awareness and without unifying qualities?

name: François ALFONSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our Parliament must give full support to the 1,200,000 European citizens who, through their citizens' initiative, have imposed the issue of minority rights on the European Union's agenda. The proposed joint resolution can still evolve to be as close as possible to the expectations of these citizens mobilized for a more democratic, inclusive and diverse Europe. This text of contributions dictated by recent events must be alleviated in order to remain faithful to the citizen dynamics of the Minority Safepack, of which an NGO based in northern Germany, FUEN, is behind. For the question of respect for minorities in Europe, on which the liability of long decades of conflicting relations within States weighs, must be freed from the political contingencies of the day. That is why our group is asking Members of Parliament, regardless of their membership, to support the amendments we have tabled on behalf of the Greens/FTA Group.

name: Assita KANKO
text: Mr President, europe's cultural and linguistic diversity is important. The resolutions before us highlight some problems in protecting this diversity, including the definition of 'national minority'. The experience of my Member State, Belgium, in which two peoples live, shows that the concept of 'national minority' is not a mere numerical notion that refers to the population. This purely arithmetic element is nuanced by whether or not to take a dominant position. Due to the institutional balance of power within the Belgian federal government and the constitutional framework on language legislation, there is cod dominance of the two large communities in Belgium. Dutch speakers and French speakers cannot be regarded as a national minority either in the whole of Belgium or in part of it, within the meaning of the Council of Europe's Framework Convention on the Protection of National Minorities. The smaller German-speaking Community can be regarded as such if it so wishes.  The proposals of legal action that the Commission might submit in the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative "Minority Safepack" should take into account that the case of Dutch and French speakers in Belgium falls outside the scope of protection rules for traditional national minorities.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Madam President, we welcome this European citizens' initiative, which is totally necessary for the protection and promotion of minority languages and cultures. I would also like to congratulate the promoters for having secured 1 300 000 support and I would also like to say that, as noted in the Resolution, unesco's Atlas of the Languages of the World in Danger shows that 186 languages of the Member States of the Union are in danger, and one of them is Basque, the Basque language. Thus, any person belonging to a national or linguistic minority must be entitled to education in a minority language and, to that end, all competent administrations should invest in long-term educational strategies. It is therefore vitally important that all Member States implement and ratify the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities and the European Charter of Regional or Minority Languages of the Council of Europe. And it is also time for a qualitative leap and for Basque, the Basque language, to be official in the European institutions. (He concluded his speech by speaking in an unofficial language.)

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – Mr President, we’ve heard a lot about the rule of law and the values upon which the EU is founded in the past weeks and rightfully so, because those values are the foundation of our cooperation in the European Union, and without a strong foundation that cooperation will never be sustainable in the future. And those founding values are therefore captured in our Treaties, and they also explicitly include the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Europe needs to live up to that promise, especially now when more than a million citizens of the European Union have reminded us of this promise through a successful European Citizens’ Initiative: a great example of democratic participation and commitment. Therefore I fully support this initiative – action at European level in support of and in addition to the Member States’ policies, with respect for the division of competences, can really make a change in the lives of millions of citizens. So let’s show those citizens that we’ve heard them and let’s get to work for them.
