name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from the Renew Group we have defended and defended the protection of minorities, the most vulnerable, and, of course, the promotion of linguistic diversity.  We act by supporting freedom of choice, avoiding any kind of discrimination, any kind of malicious sociolinguistic engineering. Because it is about having more rights, not less, and especially protecting the mother tongue of children by promoting multilingualism. I belong to the first generation who could do this.  For this reason, we have negotiated — and I am grateful for the support of the majority groups — specifically so that where more than one official language exists, the linguistic rights of all people, of all real people, are respected.  The European Union is a meeting place for people, a place of communication, and the linguistic richness we treasure is a cultural treasure that we must openly and balancedly promote, enabling the exercise of the rights of every citizen, because it is the Europe of citizenship that guarantees all these wonderful rights in freedom.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I would like to clarify that the English interpretation was off because it wasn’t said by the speaker in an official language of the European Union. I get the idea in this debate, but then please be aware that we do not get any interpretation if it is not spoken in one of the official languages of the European Union.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today Europe has a double chance. On the one hand, you can establish a framework for protection for your diversity in your various expressions. On the other hand, the adoption of these measures can reinforce the citizens' initiative, an indispensable instrument for democracy. That is why I ask the Commission not to elude its responsibility and to commit to responding to the more than one million citizens who are asking it to protect diversity. Unfortunately, there are still too many States to suspend in this area. Multilingualism or cultural diversity, despite being Europe's heritage and raison d'een, is under threat. The resolution accompanying this debate is, in large words, positive, despite the contrary efforts of some, who see in the protection of diversity a threat to their privileges.  (She concluded her speech by speaking in an unofficial language.)

name: Cristian TERHEŞ
text: – (the beginning of the intervention was not done at the microphone) ... have signed up for this in the petition. No one disputes the right of citizens of the European Union to gather a number of signatures for a citizens' initiative in order to support a particular legislative proposal. The discussion - the subject of this discussion - is whether or not the subject of this petition falls within the composition or competence of the European Commission. Article two and three of the Treaty of the European Union speaks of the individual rights of the citizens of the European Union. On the other hand, when we talk about collective rights or minority law, the same Treaty of the European Union speaks of the fact that this is strictly within the competence of the Member States. Beyond what the Treaty speaks, I quote from a report by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights which says, and I quote: "the rights of national minorities are beyond the scope of EU law. The EU has no jurisdiction over what is called collective rights." This is the subject of the discussion: we respect the individual rights and freedoms of individuals in the European Union or we call into question collective rights to be regulated by the European Commission - an issue where it has no competence at all.

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: – Mr President, as the English historian, Lord Acton, emphasised in the19th century, and I quote, ‘the most certain test by which we judge whether a country is really free is the amount of security enjoyed by minorities.’ In this regard, I welcome the resolution of this House and its call to support national and linguistic minorities. Speaking of our linguistic rights, I would like to take this opportunity to bring to your attention the fact that my country, Cyprus, is a bicommunal and bilingual state, and has two official languages: Greek and Turkish. Please take note. I am not talking about minority languages, but official ones. However, as a Turkish-speaking Cypriot, I am probably the one MEP who cannot speak in his mother tongue, although it’s an official language of a Member State. I call upon all EU institutions to correct this huge mistake, which not only does not help for the reunification of Cyprus but also discriminates against Turkish Cypriot EU citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the protection of minorities and their rights in the European Union is an important issue, especially in some Member States. The issues of the rights of national and linguistic minorities are also linked to history, to traditions, and also to maintaining the identity of these minorities, who feel restrained, fear some further restrictions and ask for our support.  The European Union promotes linguistic and national diversity in its education and culture programmes, but cannot act beyond its competences in this matter. I believe that the European Parliament is aware of the sensitivity and also the abuse of this issue. Yes, we want to keep the cultural heritage created for hundreds of years by the wealth of nations and language groups, linguistic minorities. But we do not want this intention to be misused for separatist and political purposes. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not be lied to that there are no such tendencies in the European Union. I want the European Parliament to support the Citizens' European Initiative responsibly and with regard to its subsidiarity.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, as regards minorities, we understand how democratic a society is. In times of crisis, the language of hatred and xenophobia is growing. The slogan "Unity in diversity" is not just an expression, but a meaningful cause of the European Union. That is why the Minority Save Pack must be very strongly supported. It allows for the direct participation of citizens in European democracy and I am proud that 36 263 signatures, these are the signatures of Bulgarian citizens, stand next to those over one million European.  It is time for the Citizens' Initiative for the Protection of Linguistic and Ethnocultural Rights to become the general legislation. Commissioner, the consultation time is long over, it is time for European legislation. Now it is time for modern European legislation to ensure and develop European diversity. It is important to us because it is a European value, and before that it is a common human value.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, the protection of European linguistic wealth is everyone's duty, but a responsibility, let us remember, of the Member States. Therefore, all sympathy for the protection of abused minority languages, wherever they are.  But what some, especially in Spain, intend not to help minority languages, protected, as they are, by the Constitution and by practice, but that the European Union finances discrimination against the common language, that it pays for the policy that pursues Spanish to impose in certain regions a monolingual order by way of force, an attack on freedom , a unique aberration in Europe: that the common language of the whole nation be persecuted for ideological reasons.  This initiative is sponsored in Spain mainly separatists. They are not interested in linguistic diversity: they want to end the Spanish language in certain regions that they want to separate from Spain, and they also want you to pay for it. There's the trap.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the values of respect for human dignity, freedom and democracy, but also the rights and freedoms of national minorities are undoubtedly just some of the fundamental values of the European Union. The European Citizens' Initiative 'Minority SafePack' can be a tool to help protect the rights of national minorities, but any political approach, especially at European level, must have a well-founded legal basis. According to the Treaties of the European Union, the protection of persons belonging to national minorities falls within the political and constitutional structure of each State, which is obliged to adopt national laws in this respect. I urge all relevant actors to follow the good examples of good practice in Romania, where 17 national minorities have legal representation in Parliament under special conditions, without meeting the electoral threshold.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Hilaria feels safer in the doctor, if she is cared for in her mother tongue. Aurelio too, when they explain a problem with his pension. That language was forbidden for half their lives. Today Basque is official in the Basque Country, but so many years of persecution left their mark. That's why Hilaria and Aurelius, my parents, myself, can't always use our tongue, sometimes or where we miss her the most. That's why we need our right to live in Basque to be protected. A diversity that generates development and strengthens the Union. That is why we need and support the Minority Safepack, a European protection for the fundamental rights of more than 50 million Europeans. It does not matter the vigor of the language, nor the number, nor the will of its speakers. The selective and narrow vision of the very diversity of some Member States is required. Only in this way can it be explained that languages more spoken than others who are, only because they are stately, are not official in this Parliament.  (She concluded her speech by speaking in an unofficial language.)

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We are talking about minorities today. I myself belong to the German-speaking minority in Belgium. So I am a German-speaking Belgian, I am Belgian, I am European, and my identity is therefore complex. One identity does not exclude the other, it even requires it. Protection of minorities is therefore not a question of political attitude – the protection of minorities is a fundamental right, and the correct treatment of minorities is a question of survival for the European Union. Today, however, I would like to focus on a specific element, and that is geo-blocking. If I want to see a German film in my constituency, it is almost exclusively possible on live TV. In the media library, on streaming services such as Netflix or on platforms like Apple, Access is simply blocked for copyright reasons. Unfortunately, this situation has not improved as a matter of the geo-blocking regulation – quite the contrary! We must therefore make urgent use of the revision of the geo-blocking regulation to draw up an exception for defined linguistic minorities. In my region in Belgium, or in South Tyrol, for example, this would be possible without any problems, because these regions are clearly limited geographically. These areas could very easily be attributed to the directly adjacent language area in terms of licensing. Ladies and gentlemen, we have managed to dismantle borders in our border areas. We must not allow these very limits to be artificially raised again on the Internet.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank you for a very rich debate this evening, with very interesting perspectives and thought-provoking statements from different speakers. And I may add, I have heard something definitely new in certain areas, and this is definitely something we should look into and reflect on. But let me start by saying that for the Commission, inclusion and respect for the rich cultural diversity of Europe is one of its main priorities and objectives. ‘United in diversity’ is the motto of the European Union. The Commission confirms its commitment both to policy support and funding. Respect for the rights of persons belonging to minorities is part of the founding values of the European Union and its, if I may say so, DNA. The principle is explicitly mentioned in the Treaty on the European Union. It’s not only compatible but part of our European identity. Moreover, any discrimination on the basis of membership of a national minority is explicitly prohibited under Article 21 of the Union’s Charter of Fundamental Rights. The adoption of the EU Anti-racism Action Plan 2020-2025 is a clear example of the role the Commission aims to play in this regard. Another good example of concrete policy action involving minorities is the recently-adopted EU Roma framework. As I indicated, this debate is timely, as the College has another few weeks to finalise the Commission’s formal answer to the initiative. Thank you again for this very fruitful, interesting and inspiring debate.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I am pleased that the European Parliament has put minority safepack on its agenda, supported by more than one million citizens across Europe. It is important that the European Union finally effectively address the initiative involving more than 50 million indigenous citizens belonging to national minorities. In some European countries and regions, successful minority protection guarantees are already in place, which can serve as an example. The European Union has so far treated the protection of minorities as a subsidiarity issue, but unfortunately often it is the Member States that do not ensure equal rights for indigenous minorities, so the EU must lead by example and take on the role of rights defender. To this end, it is important for the European Union to develop a legal framework to promote the survival of national minorities in its territory and the preservation of their mother tongue, culture and national identity. By developing such a legal framework and applying an appropriate monitoring mechanism, the EU would demonstrate that it is indeed doing something about the protection of minorities' rights. I trust that, over time, the initiative will also have a positive impact on neighbourhood and associated countries, as well as the legal framework developed and the rights they have for citizens living in their territory.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – 'Protection of minorities – one million signatures for the diversity of Europe' is only the fifth of a total of six citizens' initiatives that have succeeded in fulfilling the formal conditions laid down by the Treaty of Lisbon for consideration by the European Commission and also bridles the dispute before the EU Court of Justice over the jurisdiction of the latter to adopt it. In this case, it is also best to reflect the added value of this instrument not only to strengthen the voice of citizens in formulating and guiding policies at EU level, thus reducing the sense of democratic deficit, but also to find topics on the agenda of the EU institutions that concern people's daily lives, but are politically sensitive and therefore not supported by individual Member States or (European) political groups. The protection of minorities is one of the fundamental values of the EU referred to in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. As such, and as part of the Universal Human Rights Corps, the rights of minorities can never be an internal matter for the Member States. At European level, at least minimum standards of protection of the rights of minorities need to be harmonised and mechanisms for monitoring the implementation of minority rights should be linked inextricably to instruments for the protection of human rights and the rule of law. I expect the European Parliament to take a clear position in this direction in the next stages of the initiative.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We have reached a very important moment on the rights of indigenous national minorities in Europe. The success of the Minority Safepack European Citizens' Initiative, supported by more than one million signatures, has given hope to the more than 50 million European citizens who feel part of a national, ethnic or linguistic minority. With such legitimacy, the European Commission cannot leave a question that affects more than 10% of the EU's total population without saying a word. Ostrich politics must end. In recent decades, the legal frameworks, policies and programmes developed at European level have become so diverse that they can now directly affect the situation of citizens and the realisation of their rights. The european parlement decision aims to encourage the European Commission to take into account, among other factors, the situation and the development of the rights of indigenous national minorities when designing European policies and programmes. This is a unique opportunity, which is not only about the current European Union and its citizens, but also a message to the candidate countries on the road to European integration that the European Union is taking seriously the development of the rights of national and linguistic minorities. Here in the European Parliament, we have spoken many times in order to protect the rights of indigenous national and linguistic minorities, and it is now up to the European Commission to take action! Thank you.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Europe's strength lies in the linguistic and cultural diversity of nations and national minorities, in addition to the Christian-Jewish culture. We should not see this as a burden, but as a value. Linguistic diversity, multilingualism is a huge advantage, not a disadvantage – I can attest to this myself as a bilingual desicgued person. As far as the legal situation of historical minorities is concerned, we know a number of positive examples in Europe, it is enough to mention the situation of Swedes in Finland or Germans in South Tyrol. However, as an active member of the Committee on Petitions, I could also inform you of a number of member states' excesses towards national minors, in particular as far as language use is concerned. There is now a classic double standard: while we monitor, monitor and hold to account the copenhagen criteria in the case of candidate states, we do not have a well-standing legal standard covering all Member States with regard to the situation of indigenous national minorities living in the Member States of the European Union. Therefore, the minority safe pack initiative, signed by more than 1.2 million citizens, must be taken seriously and respected. I call on colleagues to vote in favour of this resolution and the European Commission to respond to citizens' legitimate demands with an ambitious draft law.

name: Christian SAGARTZ
text: Writing. – 50 million people in the European Union belong to a national or linguistic minority. However, the teaching of ethnic languages is becoming increasingly difficult. Due to demographic developments and the lack of opportunities for development, ethnic groups are increasingly being sidelined. In order for this cultural heritage to continue to exist in the future, we need not only financial support but also awareness in our society. In many regions, linguistic skills are to be preserved and promoted. There are 6 indigenous ethnic groups in Austria. In Burgenland alone, almost 20,000 Burgenland-Croats live, 2.4 percent of the Burgenlanders have Hungarian as their mother tongue, and 0.1 percent have Romanes as their colloquial language. In a modern, democratic society, in addition to raising awareness, tolerance, protection against discrimination, we also need the legal basis and recognition, because minorities contribute to an indispensable part of our society. In a common Europe of diversity, every knowledge of language is an important door opener and creates many opportunities.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: Writing. – I am very pleased that, many years after the idea of a European Citizens' Initiative for the Protection of Minorities was born, today the European Parliament's plenum is debating the rights of national minorities. It is very important that, following the debate, a Parliamentary resolution is taken on the subject. It is also a premier that the EP is adopting a resolution on the rights of indigenous ethnic minorities in Europe for the first time. In Europe, this issue affects 50 million citizens, so many of us belong to an indigenous national or linguistic minority. We expect nothing less from our initiative than to eliminate the Copenhagen dilemma, so that the Union can hold not only the countries that are about to join, but also its own Member States to guarantee the rights of national minorities. We are witnessing the result of many years of work. Following the initiative, the European court procedure, the collection of signatures, the legal proposal work, the minority protection initiative has just reached the stage of position before the plenum. I call on my fellow Members to vote in favour of the Minority SafePack initiative. I hope that the EP strongly supports the resolution by a large majority. I expect the European Commission to start legislating without delay on the basis of minority safepack proposals and Parliament's resolution, as the minority protection initiative reflects the will of more than one million European citizens to be signed.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Anna Deparnay-Grunenberg, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European Year of Rail (2021) (COM(2020)0078 – C9-0076/2020 – 2020/0035(COD)) (A9—0191/2020).

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the It has been a great honour for me to be able to negotiate this dossier for Parliament. The response has been enormous and expectations are high. I am therefore very happy and satisfied that we have been able to conclude the negotiations under these difficult conditions. The year of the railways 2021 can therefore start on time.  Negotiations were not difficult solely because of the Corona pandemic and our working conditions, as you all know. Parliament also had a clear claim – as opposed perhaps to the Council at the beginning – that the Year of Rail should be more than just a marketing campaign. Yes, it is important that we celebrate and promote rail as an environmentally friendly means of transport with great cultural importance for Europe. At the same time, we want to initiate improvements this year in order to actually strengthen the railways. Without a shift to rail, we will not be able to achieve the climate targets set. Around one third of all CO2 emissions in the EU come from the transport sector. Since the 1990s, they have risen by twenty percent. The main causes are the internal combustion engine on the road and the aviation sector. There is no doubt about this: climate-friendly rail must be the backbone of the sustainable transport turnaround in the future. My personal motto for these negotiations was therefore: "2021, a European year of rail - yes, please, but right!" Rail policy must once again be a priority, because under the current framework conditions we will simply not be able to achieve this urgent shift to rail. A negative example is, for example, unfair competition between modes of transport at the expense of rail. Route charges are mandatory for each railway line; on the road, tolls are a voluntary matter for the Member States. However, there are positive signs of a change of policy. At the beginning of the legislature, I missed the word 'rail' in the mission letter to DG MOVE. Rail is now playing a prominent role in the Commission's new Sustainable and Smart Mobility Strategy – and that is important. Perhaps Corona was also a wake-up call here, because the railways have shown how important it is for our security of supply. Perhaps this pandemic has also shown us all that we are intertwined, that everything is intertwined. And we know that the climate crisis threatens to slip into even more uncertain times. We need to decarbonise our mobility. What do we want to achieve with this year of rail? The development of a connectivity index. The attractiveness of a connection can be derived primarily from the travel time from A to B. Such an index should help to identify connections in the European rail network that would have a disproportionate benefit for the entire network. This data will be valuable for targeted investments in future infrastructure development. Although billions have already flowed, as we know, the European rail network is still a patchwork today, and there is a lack of good cross-border connections – we need to do better. Here we call for the completion of the trans-European rail corridors.  But in the shadow of this, we must also think of the small so-called missing left. Many people live – and today we have had linguistic diversity – in internal border regions and have little access to good rail passenger transport. We need to improve that. A Green Rail Label is also to be developed to show at a glance how the goods were transported by rail and with which CO2 footprint. However, we must also make the railways themselves more attractive and do not want to leave the companies out of duty. It must be easier to book international train tickets and get information. We need a common booking platform, and good passenger rights are also included.  Society's interest in the European Year of Rail 2021 is huge, and that is why we are also pleased that contact points are now being set up in the Member States. I call for them to be set up quickly. We must dare to conduct a pan-European discourse on the railways this year. How much money does it take to invest in rail infrastructure – I'm just mentioning digitization and electrification? How do we deal with externalities? How do we tax kerosene in the future? How can toll systems help us achieve our goals, our climate goals and generate money for the rail sector? These are all questions that I hope to be able to kick-start in this lively year of the railways; also, of course, the question of the resources of the Recovery Fund. How can these funds be used as a priority for the development of the railways? Of course, if there is already debt for the future generation, it must also have added value for them, so that "train instead of flight" actually works. So now the rail sector is once again a source of hope, and we hope to achieve a real renaissance of rail this year. The announcement of new night train services also shows us that we are on the right track and that the young generation has understood many things. It is and seems perhaps paradoxical in these difficult, restrictive times, when we are all being called upon not to travel and to have as little contact as possible, to start the Year of the Railways with jubilation. But let us perhaps look at it in such a way that together we want to awaken the longing for a conscious journey – sustainable and climate-friendly. After the pandemic, firstly, we will be able to rejoice in our mobility and, secondly, we must decarbonise the sector. Thank you, I am looking forward to the Year of The Railways!

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, it is with great pleasure that I join you today to discuss the decision to declare 2021 the European Year of Rail, an initiative that I’m very much looking forward to implement, also with your help. Thank you, both the European Parliament and the Council, for the strong support for this initiative, especially to the rapporteur, Ms Deparnay-Grunenberg, and all shadow rapporteurs, for steering the debate towards this successful outcome. The Commission welcomes the political agreement reached by the co-legislators on 12 November, which was already endorsed by the Committee on Transport (TRAN) and COREPER, and I look forward to your final decision in this session. The designation of the European Year of Rail will be a unique opportunity to promote rail among our citizens and businesses, but also to reflect and discuss how to make it a more attractive option for transport and travel around Europe. Most importantly, we want to reach out beyond rail’s usual supporters and to young people in particular. We will also cover key themes such as tourism, regional connectivity, cultural heritage, accessibility, equality, education and employment and look at how rail contributes to all of them. The European Year of Rail underlines the importance that this Commission attaches to meeting the Green Deal objectives for transport, including a 90% reduction in transport emissions by 2050. Rail also features prominently in our new sustainable and smart mobility strategy. If the strategies are a recipe for a modern future-proof mobility system, rail is certainly one of its main ingredients. I want to stress three aspects. First, the debates and discussions during next year will drive our work to get more passengers and goods using rail. As you know, in 2021 we will present initiatives targeting both. We will also launch a study on the feasibility of creating a rail connectivity index that shows the potential of rail to compete with other transport modes. For the green label, on which I welcome your views, we’ll look at establishing an EU framework for the harmonised measurement of transport and logistics summations, as we have already announced in the sustainable and smart mobility strategy. The European label would promote the transport of goods via less polluting modes, allowing citizens and businesses to make informed choices. Thank you for your attention and I welcome your questions and your views.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, indeed the Year of Rail is a welcome initiative to raise awareness about the significance of this mode of transport, as well as its economic, social, environmental and cultural aspects. Being rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on the Year of Rail, there are two points that I stressed in my report. Firstly, not all Member States have the necessary infrastructure to enable rail connections to the rest of Europe. As a consequence, territorial and social cohesion is slower and people and industries are missing out, including education, tourism and the cultural sector. Secondly, for the Year of Rail to be a success, it is also important to promote the historical and present role of trains, railway stations and rail infrastructure, which have been instrumental in shaping regional traditions and identities and are part of Europe’s cultural, and in particular architectural, heritage that must be protected and cherished. Moreover, during the year, the rail infrastructure can be successfully used as an open space for contemporary art, intercultural dialogue and education of different forms. So let’s look forward to the European Year of Rail, which puts connecting people at the heart of its mission.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you, first of all, to the rapporteur for the quality of her speech. Thank you too, Commissioner.  The European Year of Rail, if I may say so, must be a party for everyone. I was pleased to note the intervention of a rapporteur on the connectivity index, which is obviously essential for developing rail throughout Europe, and therefore also in periurban areas and in rural areas. This index of connectivity is essential for the celebration of rail, the celebration of rail, to be a celebration for all Europeans, for all Europeans, and for concrete solutions to connect territories, with all the positive consequences for these territories in terms of economics, in terms of employment, in terms of tourism. That is obviously essential. The second element is taxation. I am obviously arguing that there should be a lower tax, that there should be no more value-added tax on rail, and also, as you know, that there should be a tax on kerosene in return. This is both a European and a global issue.  Finally, Commissioner, I very much hope that, as part of the recovery plans to be tabled by the various Member States, there will be very strong attention on the part of the various Commissioners and of course, of the general secretariat, so that these recovery plans are not simply projects that are recycled and taken out of the drawers. , but that they are fully within the framework set by the European Commission, in particular to support the Green Deal and to come up with new projects that support all rail all over Europe, for all Europeans.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Commissioner Vălean. In order for the EU to succeed in becoming climate neutral by 2050, the transport sector must reduce its emissions by 90% – at the same time as freight transport is expected to increase by 80% and passenger transport by 50% by the same year. An important part of the strategy for green and sustainable transport must therefore be to create the conditions for a greater proportion of both freight and passenger transport to go by rail rather than by road and by air as it is today. If we are to succeed in this, we must give priority to a few things: firstly, we must ensure that we have proper investment so that we ensure that the trans-European transport network is completed on time.  Secondly, we must make it easier to travel by train in Europe – with good passenger rights, a better and simpler ticket booking system and a night train network.  Thirdly and finally, we must also create a functioning labour market for the 600 000 Europeans working in this sector, i.e. the workers who will ultimately enable us to increase both freight and passenger transport by train.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, next year we are celebrating the European Year of Railways, a magnificent opportunity to disseminate what is now a transport system of a mainly European nature.  The railway has coexisted with all of us, generation after generation, being a direct part of the progress and industrialization that Europe saw in the nineteenth century. But, ladies and gentlemen, I strongly hope that the year 2021 will not be limited only to being a mere campaign of dissemination; the year 2021 must be the turning point to get what many of us have been fighting for many years: the famous Mediterranean runners and Atlantic runners in Spain... In short, European corridors, all over Europe.  It is of little or no use for us to celebrate the European Year of Railway if there are still whole European regions that do not have a railway system typical of the 21st century.  Ladies and gentlemen, Europe is not only built in the main European capitals, Europe is also built in the far corners of Brussels: places such as Murcia, Extremadura, Algeciras or Galicia, in short, cities that have railway connections today of the nineteenth century and which, unfortunately, next year or nothing will have to celebrate.  That is precisely why I call on all Member States to make 2021 the year of the real commitment to move forward with the achievement of european corridors. I hope and hope that, in the not too distant future, we can truly come here, to this House, to commemorate that all European citizens, without exception, have a wonderful mode of transport such as the train. That depends on everything, and it also depends on our responsibility and all of us.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, the European Commission has proposed making 2021 the European Year of Rail. Very well. Yet it is indeed the European Union, through its repeated failures, in defiance of democratic opposition, that is responsible for the destruction of this public service. Total liberalisation and opening up to competition in the sector have drastically reduced the market share of our national companies, resulting in the closure of the lines, the acceleration of rural desertification and the breakdown of our territorial cohesion. You have imposed the end of the French public service of rail. You have prohibited favouring a national company for public service missions. You have imposed this destructive scheme, with the active complicity of the right, the left and the pseudo-greens, all globalists. You have chosen the year 2021, because it is marked by several events, including the anniversary of the very first rail link between Paris and Brussels and the 40th anniversary of the TGV. But in reality, 2021 marks above all the umpteenth year of disastrous management by the Brussels technocrats, with the abandonment of rural areas or the subcontracting that generates insecurity due to the non-control of radicalisation. In 2019, the Court of Auditors painted a damning picture of regional trains: deterioration in the quality of service, inadequate supply and a steady increase in operating costs - the causes being the directives of the European Union. Wherever you intervene, you destroy. For years, the National Rally defended French interests. We will continue to do so in the "Identity and Democracy" group, the only opposition in this Chamber, and tomorrow, from the Élysée Palace, through the voice of Marine Le Pen. The European Union must stop imposing its death-bearing directives, relayed by its lackey Emmanuel Macron, and it must change its model to finally build the Europe of nations, which we alone propose.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is great to see how our hard work to build commitment to European rail is finally starting to bear fruit. The fact that we are now announcing 2021 to be the year of European rail is a sign of that. Let that year be a catalyst for a train renaissance in Europe, as we are making efforts to remove bottlenecks in the railways, as we make it easier to book international train journeys, as we fix more night train lines across the continent and then we strengthen rail passengers' rights instead of weakening them. The train must become the backbone of the European transport network. Let us make 2021 the starting point to achieve just that!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable colleagues, the year of rail transport will, of course, promote railways as a sustainable, innovative and safe mode of transport that can guarantee basic services even in times of unexpected crises.  This was confirmed by the strategic role of rail transport in connectivity during the pandemic we are experiencing. Along with road transport, and I would say more, the transport of both people and basic goods, which is even more important than the transport of goods, because here had to save lives, were of decisive importance at the beginning of the crisis, and here the railway helped a lot.  There is, of course, a need to improve the Cross-Border Strategy by addressing intermodal connectivity in South-East Europe. The Ten Network has not yet been developed in both member states and member states that are candidates for membership. I can mention here a topic that has been quite the focus of public attention lately, and this is the reluctance of the deep state in Skopje to finally build the so-called Corridor No 8, which will connect the Black and Adriatic Seas through Sofia, through Skopje, through Tirana; Kosovo, of course, will be connected and this will help the entire southern flank of the European Union a lot. This needs to be changed, honorable.  New strategic routes along this connecting several Balkan capitals should also be added. Then the small regions will become advanced, is the time over, Mr. Chairman? Well, what needs to be known is that the railway is the future and it has to be invested a lot.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I really would like to thank Anna Deparnay-Grunenberg, our rapporteur. I have to say her enthusiasm and inclusiveness stands as a role model to all of us. She and her team have been truly fantastic. But I think this file has been popular across all of the political Groups, because there is an understanding of the potential of rail to seriously have an impact on the disruption of the flow of carbon into the atmosphere and to be a real positive contributor towards our task in dealing with climate change. But we have to be honest: there’s a contradiction often between our words and our actions. If we truly are going to have a year of rail and support rail, then we have to examine the fact that we are presently subsidising, for example, regional airports, some of which are unprofitable, operated by low cost carriers and are amongst the biggest carbon emitters in Europe. We have to be honest that many Member States are dismantling their rail network with the closure of regional stations and the isolation of remote areas that put people back on the roads and into individual vehicles. This can’t go on. Rail is the way forward, but it needs to be backed up by investment and action, not just words.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Mr President, the advantages of transport by rail are so evident that promotion of rail as a mode of transport is not really needed. Rail transport is safe, comfortable, easy and clean, and most people are well aware of this. Lack of promotion of rail is not the problem. The D&T projects of the past show that the biggest obstructions were politics, rules and regulations. These obstructions are man-made and should be dealt with. Less is more. We need fewer rules and less regulation; we need more action and results. That is why I would like to ask the European Commission to reserve extra budget for a study on the best way to organise the building and maintenance of a European transport rail network. It is our duty to provide safe, clean and reliable ways of mobility for the future. This does not include night trains. Night trains are a thing of the past. We need high-speed rail networks. All we need is the political will to organise it.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, the year of rail transport was announced by the European Commission to be 2021, but I think that the year of trains, railways, train transport cannot be limited to 365 days at all, it should be both the following year and the following year. I say this as a descendant of railwayers and I know that this is one of the solutions for both heavy traffic on our roads, some of the incidents that are happening, about polluted air and here the institutions in Brussels have to be very honest with people. Then, when we say that we promote rail transport, but reduces funding under the Connected Europe programme, we have to say why.  Over the past 30 years, the ratio of freight traffic on the railways and on the road has remained absolutely unchanged. Intermodal transport must be encouraged and this must happen with a regulation to be adopted by us. That reform in the sector is taking so long is only brussels' responsibility. So the funding has to be dignified. I hope that the Multiannual Financial Framework will complete all the key rail corridors in Central and Eastern Europe that are lagging behind in this regard.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there are just over two weeks left before the start of the European Year of The Railway, an initiative which aims to attract more users and goods to the train, regarded as one of the most energy-efficient and environmentally friendly modes of transport and a key part of the sustainable mobility that accompanies the new Green Pact.  To achieve this it is necessary to put users in the spotlight and offer them a more comfortable, safer, greener, more accessible and more socially sustainable transport alternative, and at an affordable price.  But significant investment and a budget suitable at all levels, including recovery plans, are also needed to achieve real connectivity across the European Union, including in rural and remote areas; investments to create a true single, modern, interoperable and more resilient European railway area.  The train has been, since its inception, a vertebrate and driving element of the Union's territorial and socio-economic cohesion and should continue to be so. Let's put the tools necessary to make it a real alternative.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Velean, this report on the European Year of the Railway insists that policies to support this sector are a very positive tool for combating climate change. If we are able to turn into European national networks that have set out the logic of investment and the use and management of infrastructure and trains, we will be taking a decisive step towards moving towards decarbonised and sustainable mobility, which is requested by the Green Pact.  You don't have to make up too much, just make up for lost time. Let us comply with the premises set out in THE TI-T, move forward in meeting the forecasts of the fourth rail package to end fragmentation, stimulate the effort in innovation, digitization and integrated management that has made the railway industry a world leader.  It is in our hands for the train to consolidate its offer of quality, safe, punctual and at competitive prices to travelers and goods who need such stimuli and offers to move towards more sustainable mobility habits.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here and in front of the screens, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good time to be seen. I am very pleased about this year of the railways, because the railways are a means of transport with a future and potential, and not only from a climate protection point of view. However, we should also take note of the fact that it is not enough to declare a year of railways. From my home in Dresden to Prague, we need a railway line for passenger and, above all, freight transport across borders. It is about 150 kilometres, including a tunnel. The feasibility study has been completed. We are now in preliminary planning, and if this continues, there will be a project acceptance in 2045. Everyone here is already retired.  If we continue to plan and build like this, we can proclaim many years of the railways – we will not finish a railway line. Railway lines do not only have to be discussed, they have to be built, and unfortunately this is not possible because of EU rules, because of planning law. Those who call for years on the railways must finally make progress in terms of planning law, permitting procedures and implementation. That does not happen. That is why, unfortunately, it is only propaganda and not the railway line that remains.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Mr President, for almost 40 years now, the EU has been choosing a special annual theme to raise awareness on a specific issue, to encourage public debate on it across the EU and to underline its political importance. 2021 has been designated the European Year of Rail, to stir the debate on the contribution of railways to the European Green Deal and the environment. I consider it to be a very apt choice. I can see from my region – Silesia – how sustainable, innovative and safe a mode of transport rail is. In addition, more and more often, rail takes us to our destination faster than a car. The Częstochowa-Gliwice rail connection and the Katowice-Gliwice railway section are just two countless examples. We should invest further in developing railway connections in Europe, without a doubt. Next year will be a perfect moment to intensify discussion on this topic. Let’s make public transport great again!

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Mr President, rapporteur Anna, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has done. Perhaps the first thing I would like to say is that paper is patient. There is a great deal of the right thing in the paper we are voting on today, but unfortunately very, very little concrete. I have the impression that very, very many colleagues in this room are deusing their energy to look at how to make other modes of transport worse, rather than looking at how to make the railways better. I would therefore like to raise three points in the area of railways, which we must tackle. The first is the capacity problem. We have no capacity in many European countries. In order to increase this, we need investment in the structure of the railways – in France, for example, Mrs Lechanteux, this has been done, by the way, since Emmanuel Macron has been in government – and we need digitisation in ERTMS. Secondly, we need digital ticket booking, which is also mentioned in the paper, and thirdly, we need competition on the railways.  We see where there is competition, more people are using better services, more people are using the railways. Look to Italy, for example! I think that is what you should do. But what is happening at the moment, in the Corona crisis, is that states continue to pursue protectionism and prefer their state-owned enterprises rather than promoting real competition.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, rail, railway infrastructure in our history has been Europe's fortune, our country's fortune. Unfortunately, however, European rules over the years have penalised this infrastructure and this history of rail.  I welcome the fact that Europe is changing direction and deciding not to put in place rules that penalise rail infrastructure, but can strengthen rail infrastructure. Certainly, but also unfortunately thanks to the pandemic, we have understood the importance of rail and rail infrastructure for goods and people. I am proud, here from Milan, to be able to say that Lombardy is the protagonist, that Lombardy is right in motion with FNM, with Trenord to be the protagonist also in the railway theme, also in the theme of the Green Deal with hydrogen trains. Surely this new technology, this real environmental sustainability must be pushed, it becomes an important clean vector where universities, research and technology must find concrete answers from Europe.

name: Vera TAX
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Deparnay-Grunenberg, our rapporteur. In the Green Deal, it’s so important that we make trains the best alternative to short-distance flying in Europe. So modernisation of our railway system is key in the shift towards sustainable mobility. What are the two most important steps then? One, we need the network of night trains to be reactivated between our European cities. And second, rail is not only important to connect people or goods from Rotterdam or Hamburg; connectivity of people is so important, even more important in all of our European regions, and therefore it’s important that we invest in our regions, and that we invest in cross-border connectivity. That’s why I am really glad with this upcoming European year of rail and this is a great opportunity to achieve this connectivity. So let’s do this.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – (beginning of the speech without a microphone) an agreement to turn the following year into the year of rail transport. This will boost and stimulate the sector, individual travel, freight transport, tourism, intermodal solutions, direct more investment for trans-European railway infrastructures and force some governments not to transfer funds to the roads and not to neglected their regional railways, but to make efforts to restore them.  The only way to achieve a carbon-neutral continent is by promoting investment in rail transport, and I am also satisfied that during the negotiations a compromise was reached on the role of railway workers, those over 600 000 people, on the need for easier access for people with disabilities and on the ambition to develop a night network of trains across Europe.  All these steps, in my view, will lead to a renaissance for rail transport in Europe 200 years after its mass introduction.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members who took the floor in this debate and for the support they have shown for our initiative, the European Year of Rail.  This shows that the debate has started and it’s so important. I’m looking forward to what we are going to discuss next year. I can assure you that we have big plans. We presented some of them in our strategy for sustainable and smart mobility. We have a good action working programme for next year, which includes a lot of initiatives on rail. Many topics were raised here. You are all right that we need infrastructure, more focus, ticketing and passengers’ rights. We need everything to work in a very integrated way if we want to achieve a result in our work towards making rail more attractive in Europe. It is needed as an alternative way and for an alternative sustainable mode, but it’s also a business. It is a competitive sector in our economy and we have great people working in the sector. So we are looking at it with hope and with all our determination to help improve it. Coming back to the proposal, I would very much like to ask you to have this important decision adopted and entered into force before the end of the year. On our side, we have already started the preparatory work. We have had many contacts with the rail sector and other stakeholders, who are very enthusiastic about the actions ahead of us. We need a legal base in place to boost our preparation for the European Year of Rail. Last but not least, we will need you all to reach as many citizens as possible, and we will need your ideas and your enthusiasm next year to make rail a success in 2021.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 15 December 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The agreement between Parliament and the European Council has established 2021 to be the European Year of Railways. In order to raise awareness of the benefits of rail transport, a budget of more than EUR 8 million has been allocated for events and actions to increase the use of rail transport.  The VISION of the EPP, taken up by the rest of the colleagues, emphasises the practical side of the programme, namely a more efficient spending of funds and the implementation of the rules in force.  The European Year of Railways 2021 will also aim to direct funds from the Recovery and Resilience Fund to the TEN-T network rail corridors.  We aim to implement the legislative package 4 for rail, on opening up the market for services for European passengers, reducing the cost and administrative burden for EU railway undertakings and providing the European Railway Agency with additional tasks to reduce technical barriers.  The call for greater cooperation between infrastructure managers, as well as the promotion of digital passenger information actions, such as the provision of real-time information on travel offers, fares and timetables, including from independent suppliers, are other measures that will increase the effectiveness of the European Year of Railways 2021 programme.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Paolo Borchia, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on a new strategy for European SMEs (2020/2131(INI)) (A9-0237/2020).

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, outlining a good strategy for the future of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises at this historic stage is an ambitious objective and the text that has emerged after months of intensive negotiations is a solid and concrete text, which has been designed and dedicated to those who are not afraid to get their hands dirty and fight every day to do business – I am thinking of artisans , small entrepreneurs, kids who have opened startups, employees. It is a document that would also like to dispel the common place that all too often sees the entrepreneur only as the polluter or the one who evades taxes. On 10 March, the European Commission issued a communication entitled 'A strategy for SMEs for a sustainable and digital Europe', the next day – I have to say with mocking timing – the World Health Organisation declared Covid a pandemic. It was therefore necessary to set ourselves the objective of aligning the Union's priorities with the changed socio-economic framework.  Only a few days ago, President von der Leyen, in a way that we also support, rightly pointed out the role of SMEs in our economy. We are talking about realities that are capable of employing more than 100 million European citizens, generating more than half of the Union's GDP. It was the SMEs that were the ones that were the first to be affected, but they had the ability to give an answer first by managing to convert and giving a big hand to the citizens of Europe.  Let me give you a few examples: I am pleased to mention a company in my region, Veneto, which has been able to convert and move from graphic arts to the manufacture of masks; or a German supplier of the car industry, which I am very happy to cite, which has been able to develop new air filters; or think of the Irish or Italian distilleries that have converted to the production of disinfectants.  Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises must necessarily regain competitiveness, and that is why we will need the help of the credit sector, not least because we often talk about under-capitalised companies. It is necessary to simplify, in particular, if we are talking about accessibility to European funds.  On the subject of bureaucracy, according to a survey, around 80 % of European companies consider the amount of administrative procedures to which they are subject to be excessively onerous, and this report seeks to respond by setting challenging but binding targets for reducing the regulatory burden. Green Deal: the environmental issue, we must realise that sustainability must be environmental, but also economic and social, because no one – and I have said no one – should lose their jobs. With regard to innovation and digitalisation, we must be careful to avoid discrimination, also thinking of those realities that, objectively, struggle to innovate and are impossible, so that assistance and financial instruments must also be accessible to non-digital and non-innovative companies, including those of traditional social services crafts or the creative industry, which therefore need to update themselves digitally in order to maintain their competitiveness. Our companies must also necessarily be protected from unfair pressure from market giants and unfair competition.  I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have contributed to this text, and i would like to thank Mr Giesecke, Mr Cutajar, Mrs Dlabajová, Mr Hahn, Mr Roos, Mr Pereira, Mr Corrao, for thanking my staff and, of course, the secretariat of the ITRE Committee. Despite the solid majority that supported this text in committee, there will also be some Members who will vote against it on Wednesday. I am sorry because, over and above a text that has had an inclusive approach that has tried to synthesise with the different sensitivities of the different groups, I believe that, in this historical phase, it is necessary to combat the pandemic by acting responsibly and therefore thinking about the solutions that the business world needs, thus thinking of those who work in everyday life in small business realities. I conclude with a wish, because I really would like us to understand, especially at this stage, that those who do business in the days of Covid are not someone who asks for the subsidy or ask for help, but on the contrary it is someone who only asks to be put in a position to be able to work.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, it’s a pleasure for me to be part of this debate. Of course we agree with you that small and medium-sized companies are the motor of the European economy and the foundation of Europe’s societal welfare. They make up the majority of companies in all 14 strategic industrial ecosystems and many of them are great innovators. SMEs are front-runners in terms of transition and innovation but depend on an environment in which they can thrive. However, they are less equipped in terms of financial and human resources than large companies, and thus face additional challenges in complying with rules and accessing information, markets and finance. We agree that SMEs have been hit particularly hard by the COVID crisis. A recent study by a SMEunited indicates that more than 90% of SMEs have reported a decrease in turnover as a result of COVID and about two thirds have reported delayed investment decisions or downsized investments. This can have devastating effects on employment. As you know, the EU institutions have not been silent observers to the crisis. On the contrary, the Commission took decisive steps immediately and addressed liquidity problems of SMEs, provided practical advice and information via support services such as the Enterprise Europe Network and supported governments to exchange best practices via the SME Envoy network. Moving now from initial short-term relief to economic recovery, the SME strategy becomes the reference tool of support. A Eurobarometer survey released on 23 September confirmed the relevance of the three pillars of the strategy: capacity-building and support for the twin transition; reducing red tape and improving market access to the single market and beyond; and last but not least, improving access to finance. Adopted just before the pandemic hit the EU with full force, the SME strategy is flexible enough to adapt to the new reality. Implementation of most actions has started and many have been adjusted. Furthermore, the Commission is pushing the effectiveness of the Late Payment Directive to improve SMEs’ liquidity. Activities will focus in the short to medium term on particularly affected ecosystems such as tourism. Under the Enterprise Europe Network the Commission is helping SMEs respond to the crisis by creating partnerships among them. It is also providing information to SMEs and supporting innovation, including through the European Innovation Council. The Enterprise Europe Network will be enhanced to provide advice on sustainability to SMEs and it will work closely with digital innovation hubs to provide a seamless service of advice to SMEs at local and regional level. Our commitment to SMEs does not end with the SME strategy. Small businesses are mainstreamed into most EU policies – for example the Green Deal, the industrial strategy, the single market action plan – and will specifically consider SMEs’ needs when updating the industrial strategy. They are also firmly anchored in our better regulation agenda. We systematically screen our legislative proposals for their impact on SMEs. Such analysis is mandatory and carried out in a proportionate way for every new proposal. A similar systematic approach to reviewing the impact of amendments to legislative proposals on SMEs might be considered by the co-legislators. The EU’s crisis response and the SME strategy support European SMEs in a complementary way. This is why it is imperative that the recovery package and the SME strategy go hand in hand. SMEs must benefit from investment and reforms funded under the recovery and resilience facility, which is why the Commission is working with Member States to address their needs in their national recovery and resilience plans. The upcoming InvestEU Programme will provide crucial recovery-support to all types of companies, including traditional SMEs. It will place a strong focus on key policy priorities such as the Green Deal objectives and digitalisation. The overarching idea of InvestEU is to simplify today’s diverse landscape of financial instruments and to streamline operations. We agree that SMEs would benefit from a single digital entry point for all enquiries on EU financing opportunities for them. The access-to-finance.eu website already offers such a service. We recognise the essential role of banks in financing the European economy, notably small and medium-size enterprises. We have seen how banks have been part of the solution during the COVID crisis and we are building and reinforcing the various pillars of the banking union. At the same time, improving the possibilities for SMEs to tap into capital markets is also essential. The capital markets union initiative aims at widening SMEs’ access to alternative channels of funding such as equity. The Commission is also setting up the SME initial public offerings fund that will in particular seek to support SMEs’ access to public markets for financing. We welcome the Capital Markets Union recovery package as an important step to increase SMEs’ visibility towards investors. We share the call for more female entrepreneurship: InvestEU will help stimulate investment in female-led companies and funds to increase the talent pool and innovation. Global markets are already an important source of growth for SMEs. Small businesses represent 88% of all EU exporters, they account for one third of all EU exports supporting more than 30 million jobs. We will continue to focus on supporting SMEs in the recovery phase. The launch of the new Access2Markets portal is an important step forward to help them. In the medium term, the portal will work in synergy with other information portals and databases for businesses, notably the matchmaking portal of the Enterprise Europe Network and the single digital gateway which will provide integrated information sources and support for European businesses. Thank you for listening to me. I’m looking forward to listening to you.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the EMPL Committee. – Dear Mr President, dear colleagues, I believe that this report – the result of the good work of various committees and political groups – clearly recognises the European Parliament's position on the importance of the new strategy for small and medium-sized enterprises.  The economic turmoil caused by The Covid-19 has a detrimental effect on a significant number of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and they urgently need to expand funding opportunities as well as appropriate and targeted measures. I believe that the new strategy should also focus on digital skills, strengthening vocational training, lifelong learning, qualifications and re-qualifications. Small and medium-sized enterprises should be at the heart of the European Green Pact and the Recovery Plan and supported by adapted financial instruments and a favourable legislative environment.  In this process, it is important to guarantee workers' rights, social and health standards, as well as the protection of the environment.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: Rapporteur for imco opinion. Mr President, I am speaking tonight from The Hague, from our office at the Binnenhof. Our Prime Minister has just announced new measures to tackle the corona crisis some 100 metres away. These were firm and necessary measures, but very difficult for people at home and also for our hospitality industry, our retailers and our SMEs. Although not everyone is hit equally hard, many of our SMEs now face life-size challenges, even though the corona crisis has already shown us that SMEs are indispensable. These entrepreneurs, including the self-employed, innovative start-ups, and family businesses, create jobs, create innovative products and ultimately all contribute to our economic recovery. And like everyone else, I hope we can overcome the corona crisis as soon as possible. We will therefore work from Europe to improve access to finance, reduce regulatory burdens and secure data sharing. In this way, we help our SMEs to stay afloat in the current crisis, so that they can continue to grow and innovate.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Agriculture, I would like to focus above all on the situation that our small and medium-sized farms are experiencing at this time, but also on their needs, more generally. So the priorities at the moment are clear and are to ensure stability and continuity for the agri-food chain, which has been hit so hard and so badly in some of its sectors by this pandemic. But the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises and farms in the agricultural sector go beyond the particular situation we are experiencing. And the European strategy will then be crucial to ensuring their productivity. In particular, European support should serve to improve their ability to market, to open up to exports, but also to diversify their products and services, with a view to the new 'producer-to-consumer' strategy which, I stress, must not turn into a further excessive administrative burden for our farmers.  I also believe it is particularly important in the agricultural sector that the strategy should focus on promoting young people and women who are unfortunately not very present in the fabric of small and medium-sized farms.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, SMEs account for 99% of European companies, generating more than half of the Union's gross domestic product. They provide 75 million jobs, but the pandemic makes their work increasingly difficult. Saving European SMEs from bankruptcy requires debureaucratisation, digitisation, entrepreneurship education, easier access to finance, both European funds and private development funding.  Increased attention must be paid to the cultural and creative industries: youth SMEs, in the media or sports area, but also to local producers, neighbourhood shops and family businesses, who have suffered greatly during this period. I mention two projects included in the opinion formulated as rapporteur of the CULT Commission and supported by the Romanian business environment: the development of a single SME advisory office at European level and the establishment of an initiative to create more than one million new start-ups at European level.  The European SME Strategy will define what the European economy will look like in the future, and that is why it is important that the European Economic Recovery Plan actually supports SMEs and in particular that we have this 2% allocation for the cultural and creative sector.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, I would like to thank mrs. Vélean for the work she has done on this I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Paulo Borchia, and the shadow rapporteurs for their very good cooperation. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of our economy, and we have a broad consensus on this. I believe that our words must now also be followed by action. In cutting red tape, for example, we call on the Commission to set a binding target for cutting red tape by 30 June 2021. We need a binding, improved SME test: all legislative proposals must be reviewed for the consequences for small and medium-sized enterprises. A central concern has already been raised: the SME Envoy, the SME representative for small and medium-sized enterprises. Honestly, we have been waiting too long here; we wait more than 13 months for this contact person. The business community needs this point of contact, and that must not be a toothless tiger. It must be located directly with the President of the Commission, and he must have the right to take action on all The Directorates-General, so that this can also be successful. We will spend EUR 1.8 trillion in the coming years. We will only be successful if we set the right framework for small and medium-sized enterprises. We will succeed with a successful sme, not with bureaucracy, not with regulation. We must make entrepreneurship possible, and our report contains very good proposals. Let us get to work directly and implement this quickly now.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: f'isem il-grupp S&D. – Dan ir-rapport dwar l-istrateġija Ewropea għall-intrapriżi żgħar u ta' daqs medju hu tragward importanti biex ngħinu li dawn in-negozji jikkumbattu l-kriżi ekonomika li qed jiffaċċjaw minħabba l-pandemija. U biex inressquhom lejn l-opportunitajiet li joffru t-tranżizzjoni diġitali u ambjentali.  L-SMEs, il-mikrointrapriżi, spiss negozji tal-familja, huma xempju tal-valuri pożittivi fis-soċjetà tagħna. Il-perseveranza, it-teħid ta' riskji, is-sens qawwi ta' kollaborazzjoni. Madankollu, l-isfidi strutturali li l-intrapriżi tagħna ffaċċjaw fl-aħħar xhur għadhom magħna u rridu nsolvuhom. Dawn ix-xhur ta' ħidma ma taqta' xejn fuq din l-istrateġija kienu ta' opportunità biex nisma' mill-qrib lill-komunità tan-negozju, it-trade unions u l-atturi diversi f'Malta u fi Brussell.  Illum aktar minn qatt qabel ninsab konxja tal-ansjetajiet kif ukoll ix-xewqat tagħhom. Nagħmel aċċenn pereżempju għall-aċċess tal-intrapriżi għall-finanzi li f'dal-perjodu nbidel fi ħtieġa urġenti għal-likwidità. Naħseb fl-SMEs tagħna li jaħdmu fil-qasam tat-turiżmu u l-ospitalità, liema qasam prattikament ħa daqqa ta' ħarta mhux biss f'pajjiżna iżda fl-Unjoni kollha.  Nirreferi wkoll għan-nuqqas ta' informazzjoni li ħafna SMEs isofru fejn jidħlu l-opportunitajiet tal-fondi Ewropej. Għaldaqstant nilqa' l-miżuri progressivi li jinsabu fi ħdan din l-istrateġija.
