Dejjem ngħidu li l-SMEs huma s-sinsla tal-ekonomija tagħna iżda spiss nieqfu hawn mingħajr wisq azzjoni. Illum qed nittama li dan ir-rapport, li jien inqis ambizzjuż, jibda jbiddel din ix-xejra u għalhekk li ninsisti li jiġi implimented b'mod mill-aktareffettiv.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for renew. – Mr President, we have been waiting a long time for a strategy for small and medium-sized enterprises. Entrepreneurs have had a rough year, and the pandemic has brought to our attention what they have been calling for for years.  The new European budget and extraordinary recovery fund offer a huge amount of resources to rebuild the economy, as well as to finance research, innovation and industrial transformation. This is a huge opportunity and it is important that this information reaches SMEs. However, access to funding must not be limited in size and the possibility of applying for funding must not be complex or administratively demanding. Our report clearly states what the Member States should do – not add additional administrative burdens. But on the contrary, simplify procedures as much as possible and make the most of the possibilities of digitization. And most importantly, treat entrepreneurs fairly.  This year, European programmes have supported a large number of smaller businesses, which have been forced by the pandemic to re-awaken their entrepreneurial spirit and talent and present innovative solutions or to come to the market with something new, currently needed. Programmes such as Horizon Europe or Digital Europe must reflect this and give a helping hand to ambitious start-ups, but also to established firms. As shadow rapporteur, I had a clear vision when working on this report : to set specific and measurable targets and to evaluate regularly every year whether we are meeting them and whether the business environment is actually improving. I am therefore glad that the report contains my proposal for the annual 'State of the Union Address for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises'. It is only through responsible account-folding and discussions that we will move forward and truly ensure that these companies are at the center of our attention as they deserve.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, our small and medium-sized enterprises are at the heart of the economies of our European nations. They account for more than 50% of internal eu imports. They are the main providers of jobs in THE EU countries. They have know-how that is often an ancient legacy passed down from generation to generation. They are also at the forefront of innovation, and French SMEs, in particular, are an extraordinary example.  This heritage of our SMEs must be conserved and protected and we must promote it. Unfortunately, these treasures of experience and creativity run up against the Commission's policy: unrelenting support for large groups, the permanent creation of ever more restrictive administrative and technical standards, absurd legal constraints, such as the prohibition on States having a proactive policy, or risk contradicting the sacrosanct rule of free and undistorted competition within the European market. Here are some of the countless obstacles these European forces face. The results of this policy are catastrophic.  Thus the example of Photonis, a French SME specializing in advanced military equipment, also innovative in the field of tests against the COVID epidemic we are facing, already sold to the Americans, without France being able to put in place a protectionist and national policy on these know-how yet essential to our sovereignty. A French-style Small Business Act to favour our companies over those abroad would have prevented such a drift. The crisis makes it more necessary. When we come to power in France, we will.  This crisis, driven by often incomprehensible restrictions on our governments, is severely affecting these companies. In France, the risk of SME failure is estimated at 10%. Europe is emptying itself of its living forces, preferring constant mobility to deep-rooted solidity, an above-ground world with national know-how. Without protection at its borders, it has delivered member countries to unfair competition. We urgently need to regain our sovereignty on this ground as well.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe need the best framework conditions and the best support to operate resiliently, competitively and sustainably. Now, in the Corona and climate crises, small and medium-sized enterprises play an absolutely central role in building, and that is why we urgently need an EU SME strategy that seeks to make the Green Deal work as a recovery plan – and that is also a huge opportunity. Yes, we need a reduction in nonsensical complicated regulations and administrative rules for companies. But the implementation of the one-in-one-out principle does not help according to the hammer method. We need targeted answers about what rules are a problem for companies – also to make such things better in the future. It is important that regulations and regulations are consistent and are transparently and honestly linked to a realistic implementation timetable. Procedures must be user-friendly, tailored to the types of companies, together with better advice, and these are clear points. Small and medium-sized enterprises now need rapid decisions, adequate financing and quick access to liquidity to survive. We also need to increase the number of business founders and managers in Europe through improved access to finance and education initiatives. We need a modern SME strategy that clearly focuses on the Green Deal – for a sustainable social economy in Europe.

name: Robert ROOS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, SMEs are the backbone of our economy. They earn the money, which is spent in Brussels with great ease and often in an ill-considered way. For far too long, SMEs in Brussels have not received the recognition it deserves. Regulatory pressure and insufficient access to capital frustrate entrepreneurship. This is probably because SMEs are not lobbyists. They are real entrepreneurs, men and women of the workplace. They don't have a shortcut on their phone to speak to Ms. von der Leyen, or the office of Frans Timmermans, like the multinationals of this world. But let's be honest: the proposal we have got our hands on is very solid. As the European Parliament, we give the Commission two clear tasks. Firstly, the Commission must come forward with binding proposals to reduce regulatory and administrative burdens on SMEs. Secondly, a binding SME test that assesses the costs and benefits of legislative proposals for SMEs, including the economic impact and impact on their employees. It is true that the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises in this house must be fought on a daily basis. I will continue to fight that battle unabated. These are proposals that will allow us to come home. We're about to close 2020. I wish you all, and in particular our SMEs, a merry Christmas and a good and healthy 2021 after all the adversity this year.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, in the heterogeneity of small and medium-sized enterprises are small businesses, bookstores, stationery shops, cafes, restaurants, hairdressers, beauticians, but also accounting, architecture and other small business offices, transport companies such as taxis, and others related to tourism, among many other areas and sectors of activity. They are companies that fight daily against the overwhelming weight of large economic groups and against unequal and unfair competition by multinationals that contribute to social dumping, deregulation of industrial relations and insolvency.  A strategy serving the interests of these companies will have to take into account, inter change, enhanced emergency support from the European Union by addressing existing inequalities, the intervention and support of States on the assumption of the maintenance of jobs, the defence of wages and respect for workers' rights, the creation or strengthening of public bodies dedicated to the issues of small and medium-sized enterprises and the importance of public banking in supporting the promotion and development of their activities. These are some proposals that we will continue to fight for.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, 1.24 million small and medium-sized enterprises form the basis of the European Union's economy. Before the pandemic, small and medium-sized enterprises generated more than half of the European Union's GDP and employed around 100 million employees. The economic crisis triggered by the pandemic has brought a significant number of small and medium-sized enterprises, including micro-enterprises, to the brink of bankruptcy, including in the Slovak Republic. They must therefore be given due attention when supporting and using financial resources. Traditional bank loans are the most important or resource practised for small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union, but this is unacceptable or not acceptable at all to start-ups of small and medium-sized enterprises. It is therefore necessary to give priority to grants. Tax breaks are also not the best solution. The European Commission needs to urge nation states to recognise employment protection and the survival of small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises and the emergence of start-ups as the top political priority. When drawing on the financial resources of SMEs, they should be directly involved through their representatives, through regions, as is the case with friends in the Quartet in Poland, and assistance in digitising the activities of small and medium-sized enterprises is also essential. And I also wish you a happy and merry Christmas as Miroslav Radačovský, Slovak patriot.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the strategy we are debating today will be decisive in supporting SMEs in the double transition to digital and green Europe. I underline three aspects in which the European Union can make a difference: simplification by drastically reducing administrative burdens for SMEs and setting a binding target to reduce the bureaucratic burden by at least 30%. This implies constant monitoring of all legislative initiatives covering these companies.  Secondly, promoting innovation and digital transformation, for example through programmes to support science, innovation, training in SMEs, as well as taking other measures to make the innovation ecosystem stronger in Europe. Finally, barriers to investment and access to finance should be removed. Recovery measures should be linked to national and regional initiatives in order to maximise opportunities for SMEs.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Mr President, in the last five years SMEs have created around 85% of new work products in Europe, while some large companies, as good global players, have destroyed more jobs than they created. For these SMEs, which are so important for the fixing of wealth and employment in the territory, are now suffering especially with COVID. That is why we need to make an additional effort to ensure that the 25 million SMEs we have in Europe continue to generate jobs, that this employment is of quality and that they remain competitive. With the unblocking of the European budget, we must now face recovery with projects that contribute to a transformation that is integral, green, digital, but also social, where SMEs have a place, but also the social economy or also entrepreneurs, which totaled 30% of all people who undertake, but receive only 2% of the funding, and now with COVID they have gone down to 1%.  Support for SMEs is clear for a more balanced, more social, but also more innovative recovery. Let us not forget, for example, that behind the Pfizer vaccine is a German SME. So our responsibility is to support them.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the current crisis is in danger of making small and medium-sized enterprises foot the highest bill. That is why it is essential to guarantee them liquidity and allocate resources to make them protagonists in the challenges of the future, such as the green and digital revolutions.  The report on which we are going to vote has the merit of recognising SMEs as the real backbone of the Community economy, of highlighting the importance of increasing administrative simplification and adequate support for research into innovation. The need, therefore, to create a favourable economic ecosystem that allows SMEs to fully deploy their potential.  SMEs are also a pillar of European exports. This vocation must be supported by raising awareness of the opportunities arising from trade agreements and by including dedicated chapters in them, in order to negotiate preferential conditions of access to foreign markets, to break down non-tariff barriers and to improve regulatory cooperation.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just today the Italian Statistical Office stated that, between the summer and autumn, almost 70 % of companies suffered reductions in turnover compared to the same period of 2019. There are many companies in Italy and Europe in great suffering due to the consequences of the pandemic, which in fact has greatly aggravated an economic crisis already underway before Covid. I would therefore like to thank my colleague Paolo Borchia for the work he has done on this issue for the relaunch of SMEs. This dossier, which talks about funds for digitalisation and training, is certainly a very important starting point for supporting the realities that keep our country alive thanks to their proverbial capacity for enterprise.  But Europe needs to do more. It is not enough to talk about training and digitalisation if, at the same time, we do not reduce bureaucracy and taxes, which in fact prevent companies from overcoming the crisis and being competitive on the international and European internal market. We therefore say, once again, 'no' to green certifications and eco-taxes, such as the plastic tax, which will certainly penalise our companies and at the same time open Europe's doors to Chinese products with the highest environmental impact.  We say "no" to the Nutri-score which is an open declaration of war on our Made in Italy; instead, we say 'yes' to traceability, with the obligation to label the origin of raw materials and food products, and this to protect our supply chains and, above all, the health of our consumers.  Finally, we say 'yes' to fair restrictions on the excessive power of the digital giants that kill small and medium-sized enterprises whose survival also depends on all these unresolved issues. Entrepreneurs ask us to face them pragmatically and without ideologies in order to be able to continue working, creating jobs, innovating, growing, giving new hope to Italy and with Italy to the whole of Europe.

name: Claude GRUFFAT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Thierry Breton is right: to learn from the crisis and finally aim for strategic autonomy, we must help European champion companies. But we do not have the same definition of what these famous European champions are, and we do not share the same priorities in terms of strategic autonomy. When the Commission thinks of the big companies in industry, defence, aviation and the carbon-based car industry, I think of SMEs, which provide social links, short circuits, ecological revitalization and employment in our territories. The real strategic fabric for Europe is not the 40,000 or so multinationals and large companies without a territorial anchorage and capitalising on the crisis. It is the 24 million SMEs that feed us and create jobs. Unfortunately, these are the ones that have suffered the most from the crisis. I do not want to oppose SMEs and multinationals here, but I want to show the inequalities of treatment via state aid in Europe. To date, less than 10% of the 3 trillion state aid goes to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The remaining 90% is picked up by large companies. This disproportion is not acceptable. So, yes: let us invest in our strategic autonomy, support our European champions, but let us do it in a fairer, more balanced, more proportionate way.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, SMEs are not only the backbone of our economy, they are also the legs on which Europe runs.  25 million companies employing 66 % of our entire workforce, over one hundred million Europeans. 99 % of all European companies are SMEs and alone make up more than half of GDP, but today they are in difficulty and in this terrible pandemic we must not leave them alone. Europe has mobilised huge resources for recovery, but allocating funding is not enough. The billions of the Recovery Fund, eib investments and all European funds in the next financial cycle must absolutely reach SMEs, especially those hardest hit by this pandemic in the tourism, catering, creative, mobility and other sectors.  Furthermore, for the future, we need to strengthen our SMEs, we need to focus on digitalisation, training and innovation. These indications are present in the rapporteur's text and I thank him for presenting a balanced and acceptable document, which we will therefore support.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Today, Parliament recommends a strategy for SMEs, yes. Thanks to the participants, jens Gieseke – always tirelessly on the move towards better regulation and SME definition.  Yes, we recommend cutting red tape today. However, we must take note of the fact that the opposite is happening. We have in mind a supply chain law, as the European Parliament envisages. This will not survive an SME, a small company with 250 employees and an export share of 90 percent. There are, however, hundreds of these companies in Europe. We have a taxonomy that prescribes ecological criteria for credit and corporate governance – this is a significant interference with the sovereignty of businesses. Do companies not already have to comply with the strictest environmental and climate requirements globally? Why the complicated environmental proof now when funding is needed? Ladies and gentlemen, the energy transition and sustainable production – this can only be achieved if you take companies with you and do not endanger them. That is why the Commission must now take things seriously. There must be relief elsewhere for additional administrative burdens. One in, one out is the rule that was promised to us at the beginning of the legislature. Get serious about it at last!

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Mr President, we all hope that the COVID crisis will be over soon, but the economic and social consequences of this pandemic will be reality for the upcoming years. It is high time to prove what we in this House have expressed millions of times, that SMEs are the backbone of our economy, providing about 70% of jobs in the EU. We need to safeguard those millions of jobs, preventing increasing unemployment and the deepening of social inequalities. Now more than ever we have to transform words into action. This strategy aims to support 25 million SMEs in Europe, their survival and their post-COVID recovery. It is essential to strengthen their resilience and enable a successful green and digital transformation. Not only do we need to reduce administrative burdens and simplify procedures, but we also need to fight to strengthen workers’ rights. I hope our efforts and concrete steps will help them bring our economy back on track and leave no one behind.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: – Dear Chairman, we have a very difficult year behind us. And these days it's hard for everyone. With a health crisis that I hope we will soon defeat, we are in for a very very difficult battle to recover the economy.  The fight to stay on the market, both small and large, follows, and now is the right time for coordinated European assistance to the economy due to the pandemic, but also because of the need for a digital and green transformation of our economy. This, of course, costs money and this burden must in no way fall on the back only to businessmen. And therefore, do not forget there are projects and investments that can be postponed, but the economy needs help now and immediately, and at the same time states need to do many necessary and too much time delayed reforms to unburd our economy. Then it will lead to the competitiveness of the economy, then it will lead to new jobs, to GDP growth. And may this new strategy be our guiding thread for the 2021-2027 budget, a permanent and solid foothold for our economy to preserve and strengthen it for all that lies ahead tomorrow. good luck!

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the Economic innovation and growth, but also most jobs, exist for small and medium-sized enterprises. We have been witnessing for years the trend of an ominous alliance of governments and big industry, with the result that the middle class is getting smaller and smaller, but the large assets and the big companies, the global players, are getting bigger and more powerful. Corona reinforces this trend: When the middle class suffers, big corporations like Amazon and Big Tech keep winning. We support today's motion because it at least sends out a signal that we want to correct this. But it does not go far enough. It does not combat over-bureaucratisation and overtaxation, which has devastating consequences, especially in the case of small and medium-sized enterprises. It does not reverse the disastrous trend, but it is a start at best or a fig leaf in the worst case. We will see what it is, if we look at the further political developments. For our group, it is clear that it must be a start and must not become a fig leaf.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, this strategy and the measures we propose on behalf of Parliament will be able to help many businesses.  Unfortunately, a large number of enterprises, small and medium-sized, in the field of hospitality, in the field of tourism, will not help these measures. What can help them the most? It can help limit PCR tests to a maximum of 25 cycles. Currently and since the beginning of the pandemic PCR tests are carried out on 45 repetitions. Above 35 repetitions, the falseness of positive tests is 100 percent. This has been established by numerous scientific papers. This has now been established by the judgments of the Portuguese courts on the cases of German citizens.  Let's limit the tests to 25 repetitions. We will have an incomparably lower number of both the sick and the dead.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Mr President, I am not going to repeat with data the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises for economic growth and competitiveness because it is obvious, but I will stress that, precisely because of this importance, the management of recovery funds must be very much focused on these small and medium-sized enterprises.  I would also like to stress that it is necessary to keep in mind that, for SMEs, digital infrastructures, fibre optics and 5G networks are essential and, therefore, so is the proper transposition of the European Electronic Communications Code. But moreover, the ability to manage data, metadata and artificial intelligence itself is crucial for small and medium-sized enterprises to innovate and is therefore vitally important that they have the right technological capacity and digital training that is now, in most European countries, still very insufficient.  The European digital programme is a very good step in this direction because, among other things, it will enable access to supercomputers and advanced digital training. And, for all this, we have to conclude today the agreement which has taken place in this area this morning and has been closed between Parliament and the Council, on the Digital Europe programme, which we really have to welcome.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union already needed to monitor its industrial strategy before the pandemic. The pandic shock, relatively symmetrical in terms of health, but very asymmetrical in economic and social terms, has made this modernisation even more urgent. A strategy combining energy transition, digital transition, new sustainability and climate challenges, valuing people and tackling inequalities must be the essential pillar in small and medium-sized enterprises. I welcome this own-initiative report which highlights the essential conditions for SMEs to thrive and be structuring in the new European industrial strategy, including through easier and simplified access to finance, investment and venture capital and support for the qualification of workers and the modernisation of processes and technologies.  SMEs must be trained to be able to make the most of European and national funds, improving their productivity, ensuring better working conditions and attracting talent and knowledge, thus contributing to the development of the communities in which they are included and to reducing inequalities. Finally, the SME strategy should also be aligned with the sme definition review, which should optimise the viability, sustainability and economic, social and environmental impact of these companies.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, your strategy provides no way out of the pressing impasses for the self-employed with no or very few staff. Your design concerns the largest companies that are either linked to business groups or play an important role in high-risk activities. These are supported, in conditions of new crisis and acute international competition. The former are, for you, just a structural problem from the point of view of social cohesion. The self-employed, like the employed, will pay the bill for a strategy that leads them to the padlock, deprives them of basic rights and social services, which are constantly degraded and commercialised in the name of the competitiveness of national capitalist economies and the euro area. The Communist Party of Greece is promoting concrete proposals to reduce them: extending the tax-free threshold, lowering their taxes, writing off debts. The perspective lies in joint action and alliance with workers in each country to overturn this policy, bringing the needs of the people to the fore with another organization of the economy and society.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. 99% of our companies are small and medium-sized companies. They create the most training places, they create the most jobs, they are the number one innovation engine and the backbone of our European economy. 90% of our small businesses feel the economic consequences of COVID-19, 40% have liquidity problems due to the crisis, and we all – and companies in particular – are still suffering from lockdowns and restrictions. Even before the crisis, our companies complained about too much regulation and too much bureaucracy, about complicated rules on data protection, about many reporting and documentation obligations.  I think it now takes three things to support our businesses at this difficult, challenging time. Firstly, we must ensure the solvency of our small and medium-sized enterprises. There must be no wave of insolvency. In other words, the Commission must swiftly examine the liquidity aid that is granted in the Member States. It is also important that we finally implement the preventive restructuring directive in all Member States, thereby facilitating restructuring for companies. Secondly, we need to cut red tape. I am thinking in particular of the taxonomy area, which does not create new conditions. Last but not least, we need to support companies in their digital transformation. It would be a huge advantage if in future government procedures could be carried out digitally online.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: – Mr President, the current crisis has had a tremendous effect on one of the pivotal driving forces of the European economy. European SMEs have been the majority of European businesses and account for a large number of employees in Europe. Hundreds of millions of jobs and more than 99% of the enterprises in the EU non-financial sectors are SMEs. The EU has to provide technological, organisational and financial support so we can ensure that our SMEs can overcome the effects of this crisis. Our companies have to remain competitive on the global market. In order to achieve this, several measures have to be taken, adequate liquidity has to be provided, adequate measures to support the hospitality and tourism industry are needed. We need to have action aimed at tackling skills mismatches and additional training for our employees to overcome the challenges of the new working environment. We have to help our companies to be the engine of economic and social prosperity.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it’s good to speak from this podium, usually reserved for Presidents, Prime Ministers, Kings, Sakharov Prize winners and even the Pope. SMEs represent 99% of all businesses in the EU and maintaining a broad base of SMEs is vitally important for the economic development, wealth and sustainability of any region in the EU. To this end, we must do everything in our power to create a business—friendly environment and boost SMEs’ competitiveness, a task made all the more difficult with the dual economic crisis of Brexit and COVID—19, but a task made all the more integral because of them. Better access to finance is crucial for SMEs and we need to strengthen and improve this by removing barriers to obtaining finance and by simplifying procedures. In this regard, the European Investment Bank should pay particular attention to SMEs. Digitalisation has the potential to offer huge benefits to SMEs, such as providing new opportunities to offer digital services or products, and expanding market access. Here SMEs still need support. Yes, access to funding, but also access to information, skills and technology. We need to address digital skills and SMEs, and we should consider the creation of an SME voucher programme, Commissioner. Lastly, we need to ensure that the Green Deal is an economic opportunity for SMEs. I believe it is imperative not to impose an undue regulatory burden on SMEs as we may shoot ourselves in the foot by dampening innovation and potentially even slowing down our transition to a low-carbon and more digital economy.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, the importance of SMEs to our economy has already been said here, as they are the backbone.  The Commission's SME strategy needs to be reviewed, and the damage caused by the COVID crisis must be incorporated. This economic crisis is bringing many small businesses to the brink of insolvency. They are shops, hospitality, small industries fundamental to social cohesion. For this it is necessary to finance under conditions, which have access. In addition to COVID, we have structural challenges to solve. We need to make sure that Next Generation EU reaches our SMEs. There will be no success in digital and ecological transition if we do not incorporate them into this opportunity. To do this we must break down administrative barriers and simplify procedures.  I welcome the progress in Horizon Europe, which will allow them and innovation. So will advances in digital, but let us remember: recovery will be uneven and unfair if recovery funds do not reach our small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Mr President, when we say jobs today, jobs, jobs, we need to be aware of who makes up these jobs. Eighty per cent of new jobs are small entrepreneurs, so supporting economic recovery means supporting small businesses. Today, small entrepreneurs are in a very difficult situation and more than half of them face existential difficulties. Access to finance is crucial for them and, in particular, the situation in the gastro sector and throughout the chain of their suppliers is particularly difficult. These firms need an immediate solution based on financial assistance, or at least by remission of levy obligations. Let us therefore not allow this important part of our cultural heritage to disappear and be replaced by uniform multinational operations and fast food. Access to finance, reducing administrative burdens and completing the common market are important for the future of small business. We must also not forget small businesses when allocing European resources in the digital and green transition. Supporting small business must become a daily part of our work.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, on several occasions this report refers to the need to reduce the administrative burden on SMEs. Simplifying is not deregulating, it is not to protect workers, consumers or the environment, to simplify is to make the law simpler to understand and comply with, and therefore even to be less violated.  These days, the proper use of digital technologies helps to do this by increasing rigour and transparency, from licensing processes to social security relations, and there are good examples in all Member States. However, Commissioner, the best example is the one from above, from the European Union, which proclaims so many times that better regulation is needed. In Portugal, Commissioner, it is often said: don't look at what I say, look at what I do. Let us begin by making access to funds from the next multiannual financial framework and the Recovery Fund much simpler for SMEs, for startups, for companies with social impact, to whom I have so often heard that the cost of competing does not outclose the benefit.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the EU economy. Let us recall that there are more than 25 million of them in the Union, employing more than 100 million people. In Poland, the small and medium-sized enterprises sector accounts for more than 90% of the total employers, generates more than 50% of GDP and employs nearly 7 million people. It's a powerful force. Unfortunately, in the face of the administrative and regulatory apparatus, it does not have the same capabilities as large corporate companies. The difficult time of the pandemic crisis has clearly shown this.  Therefore, in the new strategy for small and medium-sized enterprises, the Union must ensure that the regulatory environment and economic law are as friendly, sensible, flexible and transparent as possible for them. Regulation just needs to be less. I am an ardent supporter of the one-for-one principle. Let us only introduce a provision once we have removed another one that regulates the same issue. Economic activity must not be sedated by bureaucracy.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I should like to thank everyone for a very interesting debate. Timely, very consistent, varied ideas are really appreciated, and I know that your interest in SME policy is really genuine and I really appreciate that. Thank you again for this opportunity. I also want to pass on the appreciation of my fellow Commissioners for the exchanges they had with the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs while this report was being drawn up. Just one idea before I close: The report by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy puts forward an idea for a formal state of the SME union. The Commission publishes an SME performance review annually and is very much in favour of regular exchanges with Parliament on small and medium-sized enterprises, which we are sure are going to bring them more central to our work. So again a word of appreciation and congratulations from the report.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate is over. The vote on the amendments will take place on Tuesday 15 December 2020 and the final vote on Wednesday 16 December 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Adam BIELAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are at the heart of the European Union's economy. Unfortunately, they have proved particularly vulnerable to the effects of the economic crisis caused by the pandemic, their situation has changed enormously in recent months. I am pleased that the report emphasises the importance of SMEs for European farming and declares its support for them. The final text stresses the importance of improving access to financial instruments for SMEs, vocational training, innovation, and reducing administrative burdens. The report also draws attention to the difficulties faced by SMEs on the international stage and the problem of dependence on third countries exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and the resulting supply chain disruptions. The pandemic should mobilise the Commission to work hard to build the competitiveness of the UNION economy and its autonomy and to strengthen European supply chains. Reconstruction efforts should not only boost the economy and protect jobs, but also initiate a smooth transition to a two-fold transition towards a sustainable and digital EU in the near future and make Europe the most attractive place to start small businesses in the world.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – The 24 million SMEs in the European Union provide jobs for around 100 million people, representing more than half of the European Union's GDP. SMEs are the basic structure of the European economy. The crisis generated by Covid-19 has had a negative impact on the economic environment, with the effect of reducing the activities or even the bankruptcy of some European companies. In the light of new events, it is necessary for the European Union to update the SME strategy in order to meet the current and future challenges of the green and digital transitions. It is time for the European Union to propose even more concrete solutions for the protection of existing jobs, for the creation of new jobs and for the formation of business opportunities for SMEs, improving their competitiveness and reducing their existing costs. In addition to coronavirus damage, SMEs also have to deal with unfair competition. Non-EU producers continue to rely on lower labour and environmental standards than those at European level. The European Union must protect its own businesses and become the most attractive continent in order to set up a business.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – SMEs account for 99% of all businesses in the EU and form the backbone of the economy. And while they create two out of three jobs, today's challenges seem to affect millions of them, operating in the internal market. SMEs promote entrepreneurship and innovation, helping to boost competitiveness, economic growth and employment in Europe. That is why we must do everything possible to create a business-friendly environment and strengthen their competitiveness. It is extremely important to facilitate their access to finance, as well as to remove any obstacles in this direction by simplifying procedures.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – SMEs are the basis for the growth of the European economy. These companies currently face a number of challenges, such as bureaucracy, administrative burdens, economic downturn due to COVID, competitiveness problems, transition to a green and digital economy. SMEs are vital for strengthening European value chains, without them there is no economic recovery. It is therefore essential that we do everything in the internal market to ensure that smEs have only reasonable, adeible expectations. The European Parliament's report contains a number of positive elements. I have repeatedly stressed the proposal that, in order to create a business-friendly regulatory environment, the Commission should first review all legislative proposals to see how it would affect competitiveness and SMEs, and the results should be taken into account in all legislative proposals. The SME test is important because SMEs are often disproportionately affected by the costs of new regulations due to their size and limited resources. This report also includes a mandatory numerical objective of reducing the administrative burden on SMEs, which I also welcome. It is also of the utmost importance that, as SMEs are at the heart of the European Green Agreement and the Digital Strategy, it is particularly important to support them with tailor-made financial instruments so that they can play a central role not only in restoring the European economy after the crisis, but also in the Union's strategic objectives such as achieving climate neutrality in 2050.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises account for around 100 million jobs and more than 50% of GDP in the European Union. The survival of SMEs and family and self-employed persons is the key to the functioning of the European economy, which is why the designation of memorandums of understanding in this area is of paramount importance. As the European Commission has not produced a policy concept for SMEs since the beginning of the coronavirus epidemic, the European Parliament's report can be considered a niche. The report intends to improve the situation of SMEs in three key areas. The document calls on the European Commission to develop numerical targets for cutting red tape for SMEs. The concept of an 'SME test' introduced for EU legislation can also improve the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises. Finally, the report aims to simplify SMEs' access to the European common market and resources, which is also of paramount importance. In order to combat the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus epidemic, SMEs need administrative burdens, proportionate legislation and additional resources. In the current situation, it would be particularly irresponsible to burden SMEs with the ideological expectations of the European left. It is gratifying that, in the report, the European Parliament has taken steps in the right direction, following common sense.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union are an extremely important part of our economic reality. By employing nearly 100 million people, they generate more than half of the EU's GDP. In the current reality, linked, on the one hand, to the pandemic and, on the other hand, to the increasing competitiveness of Asian companies, it is necessary to ensure that European companies can grow more efficiently by reducing excessive fiscal burdens and administrative burdens in order to enable them to focus more effectively on their daily challenges. Small and medium-sized enterprises are more vulnerable to economic crises because of their characteristics. Therefore, EU legislation should ensure that they are given the right conditions for fair competition, which is in itself needed in order to naturally identify companies with a chance of being on the global market in the future. The development of SMEs in the 21st century will not be possible without the digital transformation that is happening right now and affects us all. We must do everything to ensure that it is wisely planned and implemented effectively, which will maintain the market position of our companies and allow us to achieve leadership in this area.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: Writing. – I welcome the report on the SME Strategy, as it addresses the fundamental issues faced by these actors. Not only in the normal functioning, but also in the crisis context of the current pandemic. I would like to highlight the points that I consider to be crucial in terms of creating the right conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises to do business. Firstly, access to finance: the report rightly highlights what steps we need to take to simplify access to finance for businesses, such as improving the conditions for access to bank loans. I consider it important to extend the possibilities for using capital market financing, including the cross-border dimension. After all, the forthcoming legislation in this area should focus on SMEs. Another important topic in this regard is the development of financial literacy. Secondly, digitalisation: this transformation, significantly accelerated by the pandemic, will bring new opportunities for companies to reach a wider range of investors and customers not only in Europe, but also in the world. Access to, processing and evaluation of data is a key factor here, as is the case with large technology players. Finally, innovation: we must support emerging opportunities and their use, especially in the context of the recovery of the economy after the pandemic. To do this, we must create a level playing field and a functional environment for small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can prosper in the European single market.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: Writing. – Respectable Chair of the Sitting. For small and medium-sized enterprises, 2020 has been a year of complex challenges and worries. As a result of the pandemic, many operators have had to give up their life's work or to bear significant losses. Many small and medium-sized enterprises have excelled with smart solutions and innovation to market their products or provide services in the face of a pandemic. This is a solid testament to the fact that European businesses are open and flexible to innovation. In all of this, they need more confidence and faith in the future. The European Union must instill hope, certainty and perspective with a new strategy for small and medium-sized enterprises. We must leave businesses more freedom of decision-making and action, reduce administrative burdens and depend on the various constraints and regulations that discourage entrepreneurship. I consider it very important that, as a result of the digital revolution, more and more small and medium-sized enterprises will have better access to digital solutions and services. This requires targeted investment by both Member States and the EU in the development of digital infrastructure and services. I sincerely hope that, in conjunction with the Recovery Facility and the measures of the next financial perspective, we will give Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises a boost, because their success will be the basis for the success of our entire economy.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The following is the question for an oral answer to the Commission on the extraterritorial effects related to trade in third country sanctions, submitted by Bernd Lange on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000060/2020 - B9-0026/2020) (2020/2586(RSP)). I would like to inform you that, as has been customary in our discussions, there will be no catch-the-eye procedure or blue card questions and, moreover, distance interventions are planned from our colleagues in the liaison offices.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, it is nice that this is the first time we have to deal with each other. Once again, all the best for your term of office!  Ladies and gentlemen, this is about the European Union's ability to act. We all know that the trade situation has become more complicated, tougher and that we are increasingly dealing with unilateral measures in the area of trade. And we are now also in many areas where trading partners pass laws that ultimately have extraterritorial effects on our ability to trade. And that is a problem that is growing. We have an impact on financial service providers above all, on insurance companies, on quality certifiers, and sometimes also on public authorities. Sometimes there are bans on people from the European Union entering our partners – in other words, a whole series of indirect effects of sanctions, which have been adopted by means of laws in other partner countries. And then, of course, the question arises as to how we react, and the clear answer should be that we go to the WTO and see how we manage to do so within the framework of the World Trade Organisation. However, there is no rulebook for extraterritorial effects. In this respect, we have to look at what we have in our toolbox. And we have recently put a number of legislation in the toolbox to strengthen the capacity to act again. For example, we have renewed anti-dumping legislation, we have launched investment screening, and we have now recently adopted enforcement legislation – three pieces of legislation that strengthen the capacity to act.  But there is still a gap for these extraterritorial effects. We have a blocking statute from 1996. We set this in motion at the time when the United States imposed sanctions on Cuba and there were also fears of extraterritorial effects on European companies. With the adoption of the blocking statute alone, the danger was actually eliminated. The US then failed to impose sanctions on European companies.  That doesn't work anymore. With regard to Iran, we have seen the case that many companies that have fallen under this blocking statute – which actually requires that European companies should not be subject to extraterritorial effects and sanctions – have been granted exemptions from the blocking statute, because they were, of course, more economically in business with the US than with Iran. I have a whole stack of waivers in my office. So that doesn't work. And also what we have introduced in the case of Iran – Instex – in order to gain a transaction opportunity, a business opportunity between Iran and European companies, is not effective either. In this respect, I believe that we need a little more. And there are still some conflicts on the horizon: the discussion about digital taxes, how to deal with Internet companies, the question of 5G is included and, of course, the discussion about Nord Stream 2. In this respect, I believe we need to expand our toolbox.  And here we should – and I would also like to hear this from the Commission – see how we can actually shape our financial instruments in order to reduce dependence on American and other international banks and, of course, also to push back the dollar as a trading currency for European treaties in order to become more independent of the dollar and to establish the euro as our currency. I believe that we must also look at whether we can achieve this independence here with Eurobonds or other financial instruments, and perhaps also introduce financial instruments that are ultimately different from a normal bank and are more likely to take the foundation's approach. In addition, I believe that we must look at how we can also defend ourselves against coercive measures. In the area of the debate on enforcement legislation, we have discussed a new legislative proposal from the Commission, a law to avert coercive measures by third countries. And I would, of course, also be interested to know how far the Commission has come in its deliberations. So I believe that we must strengthen the toolbox so that we can regain the European Union's ability to act in the international context.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Now it is my great pleasure to welcome Commissioner Mairead McGuinness. You have the floor to answer this oral question and you are very welcome.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s a pleasure to be back in the Chamber. This is a really serious issue. The chairman of the Committee, Bernd Lange, my former colleague, has outlined really well what the situation is, so I’m going to talk you through the past, the present and, potentially, the future. It’s very true, as you’ve outlined, that in recent years, sanctions by third countries have caused severe adverse economic effects on certain EU economic operators who are conducting legitimate activities, and this is the case in relation to US sanctions against Iran, Cuba and Russia, and these concerns have been raised at the very highest level, including with the statement of High Representative / Vice-President Borrell on 17 July. Outreach with the US administration and Congress has also increased. These developments have shown the need for action, and the European Union is taking steps to increase its resilience against extra-territorial sanctions. First, the EU has revived its instrument against the extra-territorial application of third-country sanctions. The blocking statute already referred to was adopted in 1996 and amended in 2018 after the US withdrawal from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action and currently applies to US sanctions against Cuba and Iran. It prevents the enforcement of respective US legislation, including US judgements or decisions based on these sanctions regimes, and furthermore it allows EU economic operators to recover resulting damages. The Commission published guidelines on the blocking statute in 2018, and further guidance will be published early next year. As regards Cuba, the Commission is monitoring closely the situation following the reactivation of Titles 3 and 4 of the Helms-Burton Act. It provides support to EU economic operators in coordination with Member States and issues guidance. In relation to Iran, the Commission is supportive of the instrument in support of trade exchanges (INSTEX), an initiative of three countries initially – Germany, France and the United Kingdom – and more recently joined by Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands, Norway, Finland and Sweden. Its objective is to facilitate payments for legitimate trade between the European Union and Iran. While not a new instrument, INSTEX is an important answer to the US sanctions which caters for the needs of EU financial operators. The Commission is studying the operations and progress of INSTEX to gauge whether it could serve as a blueprint for a similar initiative at Union level. The Commission is developing additional proposals to ensure that Europe is more resilient to third countries’ extra-territorial sanctions. We will in early 2021 have a communication on strengthening the Union’s open economic and financial autonomy. It will put forward measures to reinforce the EU’s toolbox against extra-territorial sanctions, including the blocking statute. It will also contain proposals to strengthen the resilience of key EU financial market infrastructures to extra-territorial sanctions. These measures are not directed against any third party; they are part of the Union’s larger efforts to promote its open strategic autonomy, which is understood as reducing dependencies and enhancing multilateralism and the EU’s resilience, including against the effects of extra-territorial sanctions on EU operators. Overall, the EU values close coordination on sanctions with international partners, including in the pursuit of shared objectives. Where differences exist, the EU is ready to engage through a frank and open dialogue, to avoid unintended consequences on EU operators. I look forward to listening to the debate here this evening. I want to thank you for having this on your agenda. It is a very serious issue for us, and I believe that next year we will make progress on addressing this in a wider framework.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying that the extraterritorial reach of third-country sanctions does not only affect EU businesses, but it also undermines the EU’s economic and financial autonomy, and we should indeed protect the EU’s financial infrastructure, economic operators and EU policies against extraterritorial sanctions. I also trust that wider global use of the euro will reduce the exposure to external financial institutions and regulatory actions taken by other jurisdictions. There is also evidence that the implementation of EU sanctions often proves to be incomplete and uneven across Member States. The EU can and should do more to both reduce its exposure to extraterritorial sanctions and strengthen its capability to counteract and ensure effective enforcement of the EU sanctions policy. For this, I believe the inter-institutional coordination of sanctions and countermeasures must be enhanced and we need a more systematic economic analysis of the effectiveness of sanctions. And finally, a comprehensive reform of the WTO and its appellate body should make it better able to cope with sanctions.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, today we are discussing what we can do in order to protect our businesses, our companies and the Member States against unilateral sanctions introduced by third countries. First we have to ensure that our companies in general can do their business everywhere in the world where they want, if they are acting in line with international law and the national legislation of the country concerned. But let me stress that the extraterritorial effects of a third country’s law are clearly contrary to international law. They have a very serious impact on our trade operators. The sanctions have a distortion effect on competition as a whole. And let me also stress that our companies are especially affected by the extra-territorial sanctions imposed by the United States, our NATO ally. The recent American economic sanctions against Russia, Iran and Cuba especially the extraterritorial effects in particular should be responded to from our side. We need an efficient instrument to counteract these illegal sanctions. That’s why I welcome your intention to propose new legislation in this respect in one year, but it would be very helpful if the Commission were to start, already now, a consideration of how to increase the efficiency of the existing instruments.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, very happy to speak from Strasbourg. Freedom, sovereignty, compliance: these are the issues at stake. Cuba, Iran, Americans accidental, Nord Stream, Airbus, BNP Paribas, Alstom, Peugeot, Citroen... And the list is even longer. In the past, the European Union has tried to protect itself with its blocking regulation or with the INSTEX device. But isn't it finally time to fight more effectively against the excesses of extraterritoriality? Isn't it finally time to move from the response to the offensive? Is it not finally time to have instruments that guarantee the free choice of our companies that are in compliance with international law? Commissioner, you will answer that it is complicated, that it is difficult, that it is long... However, when there is political will, a path can emerge. So let's do it! It is up to us to make our partners understand that we will finally play on equal terms: impose counter-measures as a deterrent, strengthen our power of coercion, let us create our own European financial control office. The European Union does not seek to declare any trade war. It is not a question of violating our international commitments, but of being in a position to defend rules-based trade. Finally, it is a question of guaranteeing respect for freedom, respect for the sovereignty of everyone, and it is on this point, Commissioner, that you are expected to do so.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Extraterritorial sanctions are contrary to the principles of multilateral cooperation. However, extraterritorial effects of laws from third countries do not only exist from a particular capital city. China, for example, threatens to punish its policy of suppressing the democracy movement in Hong Kong, no matter where it is expressed in the world. This should not be forgotten when we are discussing extraterritorial sanctions in the case of Iran policy or Nord Stream 2.  At Instex, we need more common ground and more European capacity to act. It is true that some additional countries have joined Instex, but unfortunately the unity of the European Member States on this issue cannot be reported. I believe that this is why we have to take our own noses. As far as Nord Stream 2 is concerned, there is not only a dispute between the UNITED States and the EU, but also within its own ranks. In the event of disagreement between allies, there can be no one-way street.  I believe that we need a political solution to this issue, for example to stabilise Ukraine in particular and to support the Three Seas Initiative. In this context, perhaps a solution can be found.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, this debate on extraterritorial sanctions is really timely. Firstly, because, in the wake of the health crisis, European leaders, led by the Commission, spoke of strategic autonomy. But there is no strategic autonomy if a country outside the European Union tells us who to trade with and who should not trade with. And then it's an opportunity for us to send a clear message to our American partners as they change president, if they don't change trade policy. So, yes, let us repeat it together: it is not permissible for European companies, or even European leaders, to be prosecuted or punished on the grounds that they are legitimately and legally trading with other countries. There are examples of Iran, Cuba, but also Nord Stream - because Nord Stream is a project on European soil, whatever one thinks of the project. Well, we have to reply and to reply, we have to apply a simple principle: that of reciprocity. Technical solutions exist. The problem today is political will. I am counting on all of us, collectively, to ensure that this happens and that we can finally bring this concept of strategic autonomy to life.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, European operators have the right to ensure, in any event, the freedom to carry out their business activities without any kind of moped, and it is the Commission's obligation to guarantee this right.  Legal certainty is a fundamental element in commercial activities, which cannot be challenged by the extraterritorial effects of unilateral sanctions. The Spanish hotel sector could be a clear example of these undesirable consequences. And we cannot accept it, because let us not forget that these effects are contrary to international law.  Once again, we must ask the Commission for firmness in order to develop its economic sovereignty and strategic autonomy, while, as the Commissioner has already said, we must improve the effectiveness and operability of our foreign policy instruments, such as blocking status or Instex.  And something else: in this new phase that opens up in the United States, let's step up our efforts for better coordination in sanctions. And, also, let us try to reach that longed for, broad and deep trade agreement.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: – Mr President, free trade is only truly free when it’s fair and predictable. The European Union and the US are allies and have a common interest in promoting rules—based international trade. The recent actions by the United States are therefore worrisome. With this in mind, it’s urgent that the Commission presents suggestions on how to improve the existing tools we have at our disposal so that the EU becomes better equipped to deal with the extraterritorial effects of unilateral sanctions, regardless of the origin of the sanctions. At the same time, such tools must never be used for protectionism, but rather strengthened rules—based international trade. The European Union must seize the moment when the new Administration has come into office in Washington and reboot its relations with the United States. When we work together, we can reach sustainable growth and political stability.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union must maintain its firm commitment to human rights. It is our duty to penalize those political leaders who commit arbitrary arrests, torture, extrajudicial executions, etc. Initiatives such as the recently passed Magnitsky Act are going in the right direction. Its sanctioning regime must be applied immediately, especially against flagrant and proven cases, such as those of Venezuelan drug leaders and their Cuban or Nicaraguan partners.  But, as Europeans and sovereigns of our decisions, we cannot allow third-country sanctions to cause collateral damage to our companies. Many European and Spanish companies in particular are suffering Trump's sanctioning harassment for his lawful economic activities in Latin American countries. Companies from all sectors, from energy and finance to the hotelier or agri-food.  What steps is the Commission taking to implement its own sanctions agenda in Latin America, while preventing European companies from suffering from those of other countries?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, fáilte romhat ar ais a Mhairéad, agus Deirdre agus Kate. Mr President, Commissioner, the EU’s exposure to US extraterritorial sanctions is indeed a major challenge. Recently the current US administration activated harsh economic sanctions against Russia, Iran and Cuba in a unilateralist and confrontational turn away from earlier policies of multilateral containment. EU businesses are seriously – and possibly even specifically – affected by these measures. The extraterritorial reach of sanctions does not only affect EU businesses but also puts into question the political independence and, ultimately, the sovereignty of the EU and its Member States. I am hopeful that a Biden administration will take a more measured and inclusive approach, instead of the confrontational and binary view of trade that has been US policy under President Trump. As well as strengthening our own trade defence tools, including the EU’s Trade Enforcement Officer, it is imperative that the EU works with allies to modernise the WTO so that it is fit for an increasingly digital and post-COVID trading world.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for this debate. The strength of feeling has been well heard , so I think it’s really timely that we are discussing this issue. The truth is that these trade-related extraterritorial effects of third-country sanctions are against international law and, therefore, we do have to respond, and I hope that we can continue this dialogue as we prepare for our communications next year. We are assessing carefully all the options that are possible to counter the extraterritorial application of these sanctions. I think we all share a common interest in ensuring that the European Union’s policies should not be determined by the threat or imposition of third-country sanctions, and that European companies and businesses should not suffer any negative consequences of these sanctions, but we know what is happening in the real world. I want to give you my full assurance on behalf of the Commission that we are committed to addressing these issues and we will respond. As I say, I’m very happy to continue this important discussion during and after the Commission’s communication, which will be published early in 2021. As this year closes and a new dawn rises, we hope for a better atmosphere next year, not just in relation to trade issues but also, hopefully, in relation to the pandemic, which, most unusually, has a speaking from this podium, so its effects are everywhere. So I want to give you my full guarantee and assurance that we have already discussed this issue in great detail within the Commission and we will come forward with our communication early next year.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The following is the brief presentation of Fabienne Keller's report on the implementation of the Dublin III Regulation (2019/2206(INI)) (A8-0245/2020).

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European asylum policy is not working. The migration peak of 2015-2016 highlighted the major failures of the common asylum system. Five years later, we have still not been able to reform this common policy, in part because of a deadlock in the Council since 2016. In September 2019, President Ursula von der Leyen announced a new pact on asylum and migration. It is in this context that I have undertaken work to assess the implementation of Dublin III to assess the strengths and weaknesses of this regulation.  Dublin is a pillar of European asylum policy. It sets the criteria for determining the state responsible for reviewing an asylum claim. A few words about the method: this report is based on field data, feedback from asylum actors at local, national and European levels. Field missions to Germany, the Netherlands, Romania and France have been carried out. I have met many actors in the reception centres and asylum administrations of the Member States. A hearing in the LIBE committee with experts, representatives of states and NGOs, a study of the European Parliament's research department which provided a lot of information on the implementation of the various provisions. We draw an expected general conclusion: the Dublin III Regulation is ineffective and suffers from significant implementation gaps at Member State level. We make four observations. The first: Dublin places a disproportionate burden on the countries of first entry. They are under great pressure, with too little solidarity. The fire in Moria was a symbol of the absence of Europe and reforms. One third of the Member States receive 90% of asylum seekers: Germany, France, Greece, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands. Secondly, there are many obstacles to the determination of the responsible state: the failures in the registration on Eurodac, the biased application of the hierarchy of criteria, the weight of the procedures and their complexity for the applicants, but also for the actors of the asylum. As a result, procedures generate considerable human, financial and material costs. Yet only 11% of transfers are made. This is unacceptable for the thousands of public officials, for procedures that do not succeed. This is unacceptable especially for asylum seekers who are welcomed for far too long - months, years - before a decision is made.  Third, the migrant journey is an underestimated determinant. In particular, secondary movements are an enemy of the principle of a single asylum application in Europe. This phenomenon is on the rise. It stops the "Dublin" machine by drastically increasing the number of procedures. Fourth, Dublin's failure is above all a human failure. Dublin's inefficiency is weighing on migrants, who have already suffered trauma. The best interests of the child are poorly applied. The same is true of family reunification. Access to the law does not meet European standards. In the medium term, we need a reform of these rules. The common system must of course be changed, with solidarity, with the clarification of procedures.  But above all, we must act now. Let us not wait for a reform that will not take place for one or two years, perhaps longer. Let's improve the application of the rules today. There is a strong margin of progress on the part of states to ensure more attention to human, material and financial resources for asylum policy. There is a need for more dialogue between the asylum authorities of the Member States. There is a need to step up governance between states and with the European Union.  We will not all solve it by changing the rules. Some are flawed, others are poorly applied. We are no longer in a crisis situation. A more humane and effective European asylum policy is possible in the short term. We are also counting on the Commission to act now.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Keller and the shadow rapporteurs for this constructive report, which constitutes an important contribution to the debate on migration. We share the same assessment of the current important shortcomings in the implementation of the Dublin III Regulation. This is an area where the Commission has proposed a fresh start, with a new pact on migration and asylum. I believe that the pack, notably the proposals for an asylum and migration management regulation, and for a new crisis and force majeure regulation, will allow to address many of the challenges identified in your report. Indeed, the pact rebalances solidarity and a fair sharing of responsibility between the Member States. The pact is based on the concept of compulsory solidarity, a solidarity that would be tailored to the needs of the Member States faced with a migratory pressure or risk of such pressure, as well as following search and rescue operations. A solidarity that would be effective in all times, including in times of crisis. With our proposals there is no flexibility on the principle that all Member States must contribute, only on how Member States can contribute. The main forms of solidarity contributions are relocation and return sponsorship, and there is also the possibility to contribute through capacity measures. A correction mechanism will ensure that there will be always a credible level of solidarity in the form of relocation or return sponsorship. But solidarity goes hand-in-hand with responsibility, and the new pact proposes new effective responsibility rules. As suggested in your report, our legislative proposals include targeted changes to make the system more efficient and to determine the Member State responsible to deal with an asylum application. This will discourage abuses and prevent unauthorised movements. While the responsibility criterion linked to first entry remains, these new rules would allow to make the other criteria more effective. For example, we propose to widen the definition of family members to include siblings and families formed in transit and to simplify the rules on evidence relating to family reunification. In line with your report, we also propose to prolong the periods of responsibility for Member States. For instance, a Member State would become responsible if an applicant makes an application within three years following the irregular entry, which is an extension from the current 12 months. Similarly, a Member State would be responsible to deal with an asylum application if the applicant holds a visa or residence permit that expired less than three years before instead of, respectively, six months and two years currently. Finally, it is important to stress that the first entry criterion goes hand—in—hand with a new approach on compulsory solidarity which will ensure that responsibilities are fairly shared amongst Member States. In addition, the pact presents several initiatives to make our return policy more credible and sustainable, as suggested in your report, such as the implementation of the Frontex mandate on returns, the system of return sponsorship, the forthcoming strategy on voluntary returns and reintegration, and the creation of a European returns coordinator. Mr President, Ms Keller, to reform our asylum and migration policy, we need to be pragmatic and find common ground to move forward, striking precisely a delicate balance between solidarity and responsibility. Keeping the middle ground and balance among all the elements of the pact is the best way forward. I would like to thank you again for the implementation of the report. We look forward to engaging with the European Parliament on the different legislative proposals presented together with a pact to reach an overall agreement on the comprehensive and sustainable reform of the European migration and asylum policy.
